situation: General Motors Corporation has been prompted by lacklustre sales of the new Pontiac G6 sedan to cut production of the car beginning in April. The company announced that the Orion township, Michigan plant where the car is built will reduce Pontiac G6 output by more than 10% and lay off an unspecified number of workers.
EMC Corp. has announced that the company would lay off 1,600 workers.

Efforts to reach a fair labor agreement between UAW workers and American Axle & Manufacturing Holdings Inc. have been thwarted by the company's unwillingness to negotiate a fair labor agreement with a livable wage for 66 workers at the company's Cheektowaga gear-making plant here. Negotiations broke down July 31 when UAW Local 846 members voted 98% in favor of rejecting what American Axle said was its "last best and final proposal." During contract talks, American Axle demanded more money and benefits from workers, who have already taken concessions but were willing to negotiate a contract that helps keep jobs in the community.The company has announced plans to close its Detroit plant in February 2012. As plants in U.S. communities have been shuttered, the company has increasingly shifted its production to other countries.

ConocoPhillips confirmed it will cut up to 230 jobs in its North Sea operations after completing a review of its business. Staff numbers in the UK would be cut from 1,649 staff and contractors to 1,419 by March of 2015. The cuts will fall predominantly on Aberdeen where the firm employs around 1,100, including 700 permanent staff and 400 contractors. All employees have been advised to re-apply for their current jobs.

Champion Enterprises Inc. announced that it will close its manufacturing facility in Guin, Ala. as capacity utilization rate and profitability continue to run well below acceptable levels and any near-term improvement appears unlikely.

Sykes Enterprises Inc. is laying off 393 employees at a Kentucky call center as the company shifts its operations from rural America to cheaper operations overseas. The Hazard call center will be shuttered Aug. 29 and Sykes spokeswoman Andrea Burnett said the center will close permanently unless it can land a new customer.
FedEx Corp. announced plans to trim up to 14,000 jobs from its domestic express service by offering voluntary severance packages and early retirement in an attempt to cut long-term costs.
Toys "R" Us Inc. to close its New Towne Square store in North Toledo by the end of July 2014. The company said the closure is not part of a larger store reduction.

Motorola Inc. announced that it laid of an additional 1,600 employees during the fourth quarter in a company-wide restructuring effort. The company announced that it will take a pre-tax charge of about $90 million in the fourth quarter related to the layoffs. The company had already laid off about 5,100 workers during the first nine months of the year.

TTM Technologies Inc. announced that it will close its Cuyahoga Falls plant and lay off more than 70 people starting later the year 2015 as it consolidates operations following a major acquisition. At least some Falls employees will be relocated to a newly acquired plant in North Jackson Township in Mahoning County. The first layoffs are expected no sooner than December 21, 2015 with final layoffs taking place in April 2016. Employees who are not transferred to North Jackson will be eligible for separation and other benefits. It will also close a plant in Mexico. The company said the moves will result in 550 job cuts about $16.5 million in annual cost savings. The company said it will record one-time closing-related charges of $15 million to $20 million.

Accenture Ltd. announced that it will cut some 336 senior-level executive positions as part of a broad-based restructuring effort. The layoffs total about 7% of Accenture Ltd.'s 4,800 senior executives.
Sykes Enterprises will layoff about 73 employees at its Bismarck, North Dakota call center.

Kroger Co. announced that will close an underperforming Louisville store later in November 2016 that was on track to lose $900,000 in 2017. The 53,000-square-foot Southland Terrace store, at 3917 S. Seventh Street Road, is set to close permanently on November 29, 2016. The store, which opened in 1962, has 108 employees, all of whom have been informed of the company's decision. The company reported that those employees will be offered positions at other Louisville stores at the same wage and benefits.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it would slash its Australian workforce by about 10% or 640 jobs by Christmas. The job cuts follow an October announcement by the automaker that it was reducing daily car production from 450 units to 360 units by late November at two production plants in Victoria state owing to slowing sales. The automaker currently employs about 5,500 workers at its Broadmeadows and Geelong production facilities in Victoria. The jobs cuts will be voluntary and come from across the business.

Playtex Products Inc. plans to cut 94 jobs at its Dover manufacturing plant, the company said Wednesday. The cuts represent 9 percent of the company's 1,045-member Dover work force, which produces tampons, gloves and infant-feeding products.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it would cut about 1,700, or 5%, of its white-collar jobs in North America. The company announced that it would no longer give bonuses to employees in those positions or make matching contributions to their 401(k) plans.

Zale Corporation closed 118 underperforming stores in the quarter ended July 31, 2009 and will record a $50 million pretax charge. The charge includes $23 million to cover lease guarantees on Bailey, Banks & Biddle stores. The closings bring Zale's total to 191 in 2009.

The Ford Motor Co. is rethinking its decision to stop making the Excursion, a large sport utility vehicle that has been a favorite target of criticism by environmental advocates. The company had decided last year to stop selling the Excursion after the 2004 model year because of declining sales, but said that it was reconsidering because industry demand had held up for the largest S.U.V.'s.

Blockbuster Inc. has taken over the operations of four Blockbuster Video outlets in Lexington, and six other Blockbuster locations across the city have closed, all as a result of unspecified difficulties faced by the company's Lexington franchisee. The company had assumed control of Blockbuster stores at 2925 Richmond Road, 4222 Saron Drive, 921 Beaumont Centre Parkway and 551 Euclid Avenue. Six other Lexington Blockbuster locations have closed at 2467 Nicholasville Road, 1650 Bryan Station Road, 3090 Helmsdale Place, 450 Southland Drive, 3735 Palomar Centre Drive and 4101 Tates Creek Pike.

Midwest Express Holdings Inc. will cut 13 percent of its employees while reducing pay for those who remain and launch a low-fare airline to attract leisure travelers, the company said. The furloughs will affect about 430 employees at Midwest Express Airlines.

BorgWarner Inc. announced that 90 employees were laid off. The layoffs are part of the company's nationwide restructuring plan. The cause for the additional layoffs is part of the larger economic picture.
Devon Energy Corporation has announced that it will close its Lafayette office in September 2010 following the company's sale of its Gulf of Mexico petroleum properties.

Less than 50 employees at ESCO Technologies' plant in Glendale Heights, Ill., will lose their jobs when the plant closes. The company announced that it will close that facility, outside Chicago, as it consolidates its test segment's four domestic manufacturing facilities into three. The plant's closing is expected to be completed by January, and the majority of the employees will be transferred to the other three test segment facilities. The company expects about $3 million in restructuring costs, to be expensed over the next six to nine months. The consolidation is expected to yield partial-year cost savings in 2013 of about $1 million, excluding restructuring costs, and annual savings of $3 million starting in 2014, according the company. Despite the shortfall, the company expects its fourth-quarter pre-tax earnings to be more than 35% higher than the prior-year quarter. ESCO's pre-tax earnings were $19.9 million in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Ford Motor Co. announced that it will reduce its workforce at Almussafes by up to 1,300, albeit on a temporary basis from September 29 to December 17.

3M will cut 130 workers nationwide from its Electro and Communications business, which continues to restructure amid weak demand for telecommunications and networking parts, during the next two months.

Computer Associates International Inc. announced that it would again slash 5% of its workforce in a move expected to save it $75 million a year. The job cuts follow an earlier round of layoffs last September at the Islandia, N.Y., management software firm, under which it also handed pink slips to some 800 workers.

Lockheed Martin Corp. will announce plans to lay off about 500 people across its information systems and government services division, which it plans to sell or spin off later this year. The job cuts would be both voluntary and involuntary and should be completed by mid-November.

Delphi Corp., General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Visteon Corp. may cut wages and thousands of jobs in cost-saving restructuring plans. GM and Delphi, its former parts division, Ford Motor Co. and Ford's former parts unit Visteon Corp., form the largest employers of organized workers in the U.S. city of Detroit, and all plan to restructure.
Lyondell Chemical Company (Houston) plans to aggressively pursue NOx (Nitrogen Oxide) reduction projects at two of its Texas Gulf Coast petrochemical plants.

Albany International Corp. will close a facility in Massachusetts and consolidate its technical and manufacturing operations located there into other facilities in Europe and North America. The closure will result in a loss of 80 jobs.

Openwave Systems Inc. announced a reduction of approximately 18% to 20% of the workforce. As part of the restructuring, the company intends to reduce its spending on legacy products and solutions that have been underperforming. The company said it expects to reduce annual Non-GAAP operating expenses by about 30%, or $30 - $32 million, on a year-over-year basis.

Merck & Co. announced plans to cut an additional $1-billion (U.S.) in costs through 2010 and focus its research on medicines for the most common diseases. The struggling drug maker, which has been hammered by mounting lawsuits, falling revenue and profit, and sharply depressed stock as generic competition looms for its top drug, also reaffirmed its earnings forecasts for this year and next. The new cost cuts, to be achieved through redesigning business operations, were disclosed at Merck's annual business briefing with analysts at its New Jersey headquarters. They follow Merck's Nov. 28 announcement that it will eliminate 7,000 jobs and close or sell eight factories and research facilities to lower expenses by $3.5-billion to $4-billion through the decade's end.
Campbell Soup Co. is cutting about 400 jobs worldwide, reducing its work force by about 1.6% mostly through layoffs. The cuts are part of a corporate reorganization.

Lockheed Martin announced that it plans to close operations in Newtown, Pa.; Akron, Ohio; Goodyear, Ariz.; and Horizon City, Texas; and four buildings on its Sunnyvale, Calif., campus. The facility closures will result in the elimination of 2,000 positions. Current cost cutting measures should eliminate an additional 2,000 positions in the company's Information Systems & Global Solutions, Mission System and Training and Space Systems divisions by the end of 2014.

Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. reported it is planning to cut at least 500 jobs over the next 18 months from its customer service and back-office administration, continuing a consolidation that began in late 2008. The company would not say how many jobs are affected or how many are in Connecticut, where The Hartford has 10,400 employees. But some employees who spoke anonymously put the total figure at between 500 and 600, and said customer service jobs would be heavily targeted.

Owens Corning announced plans to close its manufacturing plant in New Braunfels this summer, with a loss of 120 jobs. Glass fiber reinforcements, woven fabrics used in marine, military and industrial applications, are made at the plant.

The MeadWestvaco Corp. plans to cut paper production this quarter, reducing profit by about $16 million, or 5 cents. because of competition from imports and falling magazine advertising. The company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., is closing plants and laying off workers to reduce expenses by $325 million a year. it would eliminate 3,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, by 2004.

General Electric (GE) has announced plans to shut down a foundry as well as cut more than 250 jobs at its Lufkin oil-field services unit in, Texas, US, amid dropping global oil prices. The decision to close the foundry and 262 axe jobs at the two Angelina County, Texas, sites is driven by the reduction in demand for drilling equipment made by GE's unit Lufkin Industries due to the plunging oil prices.
Solectron Corp. announced that it will lay off between 1,300 and 1,500 employees as part of a previously announced restructuring plan.
Aramark Services has announced that it will layoff 436 employees in Seattle as Boeing has switched its food services business to the Compass Group.

General Electric Co. will cut the workforce at its Mebane plant by 55 jobs. Declining orders from customers forced the cuts. 34 employees will be laid off, with another 21 vacant jobs eliminated. As the economic recession continues, and as customer orders continue to drop, company have no choice but to reduce capacity because company manufacture custom electrical equipment to specific customer applications and orders.

Opus Bank in Irvine, Calif., has reshuffled its mix of branch office locations, as it enters Arizona and expands in the greater Los Angeles and Seattle areas. The company plans to open six offices early 2013, two each in Arizona, California and Washington state. The new offices are planned for Paradise Valley and Scottsdale, Ariz.; San Rafael and Rancho Santa Margarita, Calif.; and Seattle and Tacoma, Wash.Opus is also in the process of closing eight branches, some of which were recently acquired, and all of which are located within two miles of another Opus Bank branch.

Eaton Corp. will close a circuit breaker assembly plant in Puerto Rico and shift the work to another factory in the U.S. island territory and to the Dominican Republic. The production will be shifted to Eaton plants in Arecibo, Puerto Rico, and in Haina, Dominican Republic. The company's electrical division operates five assembly plants in Puerto Rico, including the one slated to close in Cabo Rojo, and one in the Dominican Republic.

Gerber Scientific Inc. has laid off 61 workers at its South Windsor headquarters and three manufacturing plants in Connecticut. Top company executives also accepted a 25 percent pay cut to help control costs. Overall, the maker of automated manufacturing equipment used in optical, apparel, sign making, graphics, apparel and materials processing industries laid off 100 workers. The company also operates plants in Massachusetts, Oklahoma and Texas.

First Solar, Inc. announced that it would slash 2,000 jobs, or 30% of its work force, to keep pace with steep declines in panel prices. First Solar will cut output of its thin-film solar panels and shift its focus away from Europe, where governments have been changing subsidy policies that had boosted demand for First Solar's panels. Solar panel manufacturers have struggled amid a steep decline in selling prices for solar equipment over the past year that has sent share prices in the sector plummeting. Several companies have gone into bankruptcy. Solar makers, particularly in China, have rushed to build new manufacturing capacity in recent years as demand for the renewable energy systems grew. That expansion left the industry struggling with output capacity nearly double customer demand. The resulting inventory glut sent prices for panels down by more than half over the last year.
Lennar Corp. announced that it would cut its workforce by 35%, reflecting a steep downturn in the housing market.

Legg Mason Inc. announced that it is cutting roughly 30 jobs, or 3% of its corporate workforce, as part of ongoing changes in the asset management industry. The layoffs are across the Baltimore company's corporate offices and do not include affiliates.

Honeywell International Inc. is seeking a further 50 job cuts on top of 100 which were announced in July. The company is also introducing short-time working until Christmas at least. The firm said that due to instability and continued declines in demand in the car market, an additional 50 jobs were at risk, as well as a possibility for other action to address the loss of volume.

Comverse Technology Inc. announced a round of layoffs which have been discussed since August, is set to get underway. Over the coming month of Feburary 2010, about 500 workers around the world, or 12% of its workforce, are set to be laid off. About 200 of the layoffs are expected to be employees in Israel.

Pier 1 Imports Inc. (PIR) announced that it is considering closing up to 45 locations in fiscal 2020 as leases expire. The store closure number could increase to up to 15% of stores if the company is unable to achieve performance goals, sales targets, and reductions in occupancy and other costs.

Dendrite International Inc. will close its Bethlehem Township facility and lay off about 25 workers in October. Dendrite of Morristown, N.J., expects to close the facility by Oct. 28, 2005. The company makes computer software for the pharmaceutical industry. The Bethlehem Township facility, which opened in 2001, provides inventory management, repair/replacement processing and configuration management for a variety of personal computers and hand-held computing devices used by pharmaceutical salespeople and others. The company moved employees to the Emrick Boulevard plant from an East Stroudsburg facility it had closed.

About 1,000 employees at Dell face losing their jobs as the computer maker plans to shut down its call centre in Mohali, India. The US-based company is steadily eliminating employees including senior technologists, strategists, developers, and sales employees, as well as a vice-president.

Borders Group plans to close two of its three area Waldenbooks stores. The Ward Parkway Center store and the Metro North Shopping Center store are scheduled to close January 2007. Both stores are having a closing sale.

Pfizer Inc. announced that it will close one of its three manufacturing plants in Puerto Rico by 2017. The company announced the manufacturing of products at its plant in the north coastal city of Barceloneta will be moved elsewhere. The company announced the closure is linked to the loss of patent exclusivity and improved manufacturing efficiency. The company announced that it does not know yet how many people will be laid off.

Citigroup, Inc. announced plans to cut 300 jobs in its sales and trading unit by year end. Its securities unit cut 900 jobs last year. The current round of layoffs is said to have been in the works before Vikram Pandit, Citigroup's former chief executive, left the company in October. The securities unit has about 17,000 employees.

Maytag corp. plans layoffs in North canton. The company has already chopped hundreds of jobs across the country and reduced retiree health care benefits. More cuts are coming, particularly at plants in North Canton and Newton.

Gap Inc. is closing nearly 200 stores and downsizing others in the U.S. as it focuses on international expansion. The company plans to reduce the number of Gap brand stores in North America to 700 by the end of 2013, a 21% decrease from the 889 that it operated at the end of July. This announcement was part of an ongoing company strategy to reduce the combined square footage of Gap's stores across all major brands in North America.The company provided a comprehensive business overview of the company that was heavily focused on overseas growth. Those plans include the opening of an Old Navy store in Japan within 18 months, the brand's first location outside of North America, and nearly tripling the number of Gap brand stores in greater China to about 45 by the end of 2012. The first Gap flagship in Hong Kong is set to open in a few weeks, and the company's first Banana Republic flagship in Paris is scheduled to open in 2011. The company would balance its Gap brand store closings by adding about 50 new Gap Outlet stores in North America.

National City, a bank branch in the Pittsburgh section of Mount Oliver, will close its doors. The building at Bausman Avenue and Brownsville Road has housed banks since 1931, including St. Clair Depository, Western Pennsylvania National Bank, Equibank and Integra. Employees were given the opportunity to relocate to other branches or apply for other National City positions.

On May 28, 2010, Reynolds American Inc. announced a consolidation and upgrading of manufacturing facilities at multiple operating companies. A cigarette factory in Winston-Salem, North Carolina and one in Yabucoa, Puerto Rico will close, and production from those facilities will transfer to RJRTCéˆ¥æªš facility in Tobaccoville, North Carolina. As a result of the consolidation, approximately 60 manufacturing positions in Puerto Rico will be eliminated, and affected employees will receive severance benefits. American Snuff Company, LLC is expanding its manufacturing operations inMemphis, Tennessee, expecting the new facilities to be fully operational in early 2012, and increasing its tobacco-processing capacity in Clarksville, Tennessee, expecting the new facilities to be fully operational in early 2012.

Applied Materials Inc. announced a global cost reduction plan that primarily affects its semiconductor equipment and services businesses and related support organizations. As part of the plan the company will reduce its global workforce by approximately 1,000 positions or about 7%, through a combination of job elimination and attrition. Applied expects to record charges of approximately $20 million related to the plan, with the majority of the charges being recorded in the first quarter of fiscal 2008, and to complete the plan by the fourth quarter of fiscal 2008. The plan is expected to result in annualized savings of about $150 million from fiscal 2007 spending levels.

Dominos Pizza Inc. announced that the company has cut back on its corporate stores which incurred one-off restructuring costs and resulted in lower productivity. The company expected strong growth in the next 12 months, expecting a 25% to 30% rise in net profit for 2007-08, driven by 60 new stores across Australia, NZ and Europe.

Molson Coors Brewing Company has announced that it is finalising plans for the closure of its brewing and packaging facilities in Memphis and the transfer of those operations to other units. The company announced in February that it planned to close the Memphis brewery in early-2007. It has now confirmed that it expects the phasing-out of operations to begin during the second half of the current fiscal year and to be completed by the first quarter of 2007. It expects to incur severance costs of between $15 million and $25 million other employee-related costs of about $10 million, with equipment relocation and other facility transition costs amounting to between $5 million and $15 million.

Heinz has dismissed 65 employees from its Pocatello facility, Idaho. The company, said: 'to ensure the number of employees are in line with the production needs at the Pocatello facility, it has made the difficult but necessary decision to layoff approximately 65 team members.

Cameron International said earlier this week in a letter to the state that it would cut approximately 56 workers at the Millbury plant. In the letter, the company said it had determined there was excess capacity within its manufacturing business and decided to make cuts to the local plant. The company said it would substantially reduce operations at the plant and move production to another facility.

Ionics Incorporated announced that the program will result in the elimination of approximately 200 positions, or 10% of the Company's worldwide workforce. The Company believes that these actions, which it anticipates will be taken over the next six months, should result in an approximate annual savings of $15 million after they are fully implemented.

NCO Group Inc. laid off around 40% of its staff this week at a Canadian office focused on customer relationship management work, that the workers were engaged in customer relationship management services.

Metaldyne Corp. announced that it will close its Farmington Hills, Mich., plant by April 2008 to adjust for the excess capacity in its plants caused by production cuts from its North American customers.
Gannett Co. Inc. announced that it laid off about 2,000 workers, or 10% of its work force.

Kmart Corp. announced it will cut nearly 700 jobs, including approximately 400 positions at corporate headquarters in Troy, Mich., as the bankrupt discounter continues its turnaround efforts. Kmart has closed 283 stores and cut 22,000 jobs since filing for bankruptcy eight months ago.

Macy's Inc. has announced plans to restructure its merchandising and marketing operations. With changes being announced, Macy's, Inc. will be increasing its workforce in some functions and locations while decreasing in others so all of the company's resources can be deployed for maximum results. In total, the Macy's, Inc. workforce is expected to remain at a level of approximately 175,000 associates. Both Macy's and Bloomingdale's are restructuring their respective central merchandising and marketing functions so each brand can develop and present its assortments seamlessly across channels and provide a single omnichannel view in all product categories. Simultaneously, Macy's will make selected changes to its merchandising-related functions in local districts (administrative grouping of Macy's stores) around the country as it continues to improve its ability to localize assortments by size, color, fabric weight, style, fit, category and brand. The company will discontinue district planner positions and reinvest in new regional teams devoted to specific themes of merchandise localization. These changes in merchandising and marketing are expected to affect approximately 115 associates in Macy's and Bloomingdale's central offices in New York City, as well as about 150 associates in local markets nationwide. Selling service and support is being modified to match business opportunity in each department. An average of two to three associates will be affected in each of Macy's and Bloomingdale's approximately 830 stores (out of an average workforce of approximately 150 associates in each store), for a total of about 2,200 affected associates nationwide. The company is working to place as many affected associates as possible in other open positions. Also, two existing Macy's stores districts are being merged into nearby districts thus reducing the ongoing number of stores districts to 58 from the current 60. Trade union CNV Vakmensen expects the loss of 100 jobs at the Dordrecht chemicals plant of US industrial conglomerate DuPont in western Netherlands due to restructuring, union official Arjan Huizinga was cited as saying by news agency.

TD AMERITRADE Holding Corporation closed one of its two financial-service operations in Orlando and dismissed the staff as part of a nationwide consolidation. The company expects to eliminate 45 jobs in shutting its downtown office at 301 E. Pine St.
U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray will layoff about 55 employees, 10 percent of the workforce at its equity capital markets unit, because of the poor equity market conditions.

Ultimate Electronics Inc. will close its consumer electronics stores in Des Moines, Davenport and Cedar Rapids this spring as part of its bankruptcy reorganization plan. Twenty-seven other retail stores in Kansas City, South Dakota, Texas and Utah also will close, according to documents filed last week with the Securities and Exchange Commission. About 900 employees, along with 65 corporate workers, will lose their jobs as a result of the closings.
La-Z-Boy Inc. announced that it would shut down the plant in the town of Tremont and move some of the jobs to Mexico. It's the town's largest employer. 630 people will lose their jobs.

The closing of an electrical product manufacturer here will leave 354 employees without jobs. Officials at Cooper Industries Ltd. said the 24-year-old plant will close by March 2003, but most of the employees are expected to be laid off by the end of this year. None of the employees have been promised transfers.

MetLife Inc. plans to lay off 35 employees in the Independent Agent Underwriting department of the MetLife Auto & Home unit, effective September 19, 2003. It involves administrative and management employees.

AèŒ…ropostale, Inc. now announced that it is planning to open approximately seven Aeropostale stores and remodel, either partial or full, approximately ten Aeropostale stores, and expects to open one new P.S. store. The company expects to invest approximately $22 million in fiscal 2014 primarily related to store openings, store remodels and certain infrastructure investments. Currently, the company planed to close approximately 50 Aeropostale stores and two P.S. stores, and has retained a real estate consulting firm to investigate the opportunity to accelerate the pace of closures, as well as to identify other potential rent reduction savings.

Conn's will close 10 locations in 2014, completing review of its stores that will put the chain solidly behind its Home Plus format. Conn's shut two of the outlets in fiscal fourth quarter ended Jan. 31 and will close the remaining eight over the balance of the year, finishing up with all but five locations featuring Home Plus. The stores being closed didn't "justify the investment" needed for Home Plus, including one location that at 16,000 square feet was too small for it.
Cascade Corp. plans to close its Eldridge plant, laying off 23 workers. The workers make up about 22% of the company's wood-tress manufacturing staff.

Genworth Financial Inc. announced that with a global recession gathering, the company is preparing to make up to $150 million in expense cuts, most of them by the end of the year. That could mean layoffs for a work force that includes more than 3,100 people in Virginia, including about 1,700 in the Richmond area.

Four Corners Property Trust, Inc. announced to closed on the purchase of five restaurant properties from Washington Prime Group Inc. (éˆ¥æ·²PGéˆ?. This is the second closing of the acquisition previously announced in September 2017. Closing of the remaining properties is expected to be completed throughout the remainder of 2018 based on the timing of parcelization of each respective property, subject to remaining due diligence and customary closing conditions. The purchase price for the five properties was approximately $9.5 million and represents a capitalization rate consistent with investment thresholds and past transactions. The leases have a current weighted average remaining term of approximately 8.6 years. Four of the five properties are ground leases (i.e., the tenant built its own building with ownership reverting to the landlord upon lease expiry).

Kimberly-Clark will close a paper plant in East Ryegate, Vermont by the end of 2001 and four plants in Latin America over the next 18 months because of weak demand. Approximately 1,400 workers, representing 2 percent of its workforce will lose their jobs.

US Airways Group Inc. won approval from a U.S. Bankruptcy Court to immediately slash most of its 28,000 employees' pay by 21% through February to help it stay in business and eventually emerge from bankruptcy protection.

Texas Instruments Inc. has initiated measures to lay off employees in India as part of its global workforce restructuring plans. The company is planning to axe 1,700 jobs and reduce costs in OMAP processors and wireless connectivity solutions to focus on other embedded solutions with long life cycles. The company is likely to cut over 500 employees here and considerable number of staff could be 're-deployed'.

Hospital Corporation of America announced that it is closing one of its Florida hospitals, citing a sharp decline in in-patient volume. HCA will shut down the 162-bed Edward White Hospital in St. Petersburg by Nov. 24. Services at the hospitals will shift to three other HCA-affiliated hospitals in the area.
Bank of America Corp. (DE) is cutting about 90 full-time jobs at its consumer real estate fulfillment center in Wichita, citing a downturn in mortgage refinancing.

Texas Instruments Inc. cut its financial targets and announced a larger-than-expected number of job cuts for its current quarter, becoming the third major technology company in two days to warn that SARS has hit its Asian business. The Dallas, Texas-based company also announced that will cut 250 jobs from its chip operations in Japan, which will result in about $55 million in charges instead of the $40 million it previously predicted.

US drugs Pfizer will shut two of its three manufacturing plants in the UK in the next four years, putting 370 jobs at risk. The Park Royal site in London is earmarked for closure by May 2017, leaving 100 employees out of a job. Pfizer's global cold chain packaging and distribution site in Havant, in Portsmouth will shut by the end of 2020, with 270 job losses.

Vulcan Materials Company announced that it is consolidating its eight divisions into four operating regions as part of ongoing efforts to reduce overhead costs and increase operating efficiency. This initiative is expected to generate an ongoing annualized pre-tax cost savings of approximately $30 million, in addition to approximately $25 million in annual pre-tax overhead reductions already implemented in 2011. The new organizational structure is consistent with Vulcan's longstanding commitment to decentralized management of its sales, marketing and operating functions, and will enable the Company to maintain close, local relationships with its customers. It also will allow the Company to leverage significant investments in technology that have replaced legacy IT and financial reporting systems. These new systems support improvement in administrative and operating efficiencies while also creating new opportunities for greater standardization and implementation of best practices throughout the organization. The Company expects that approximately 200 positions will be affected, with most coming from overhead and administrative staff. Staffing at plant facilities will be largely unaffected. Following the consolidation, Vulcan will have four regions: East, South, Central and West. The East Region, which will comprise the Company's former Southeast and Mideast Divisions, will be headquartered in Atlanta and led by Michael R. Mills, Senior Vice President, East. Mills, age 50, was President of Vulcan's Southeast Division. The South Region will comprise the Company's former Florida Rock and Southwest Divisions, and will include Vulcan's quarry and harbor on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula and related shipping assets. Vitamin Shoppe, Inc. provided guidance for 2019. The company expects the Full year comparable sales of negative low single digits to flat and also For the fourth quarter ended December 29, 2018, the company reported goodwill, trade name and store fixed-assets impairment charges of $1,466,000 against $786,000 a year ago.The company expect closing of approximately 60 to 80 stores over next three years.

EW Scripps Co. announced that it would cut 400 jobs as the weak advertising market inflicted another blow on the struggling US newspaper industry. The company announced that 'approximately 400' job cuts would yield annual savings of $15 million and its newspaper division would employ less than 4,000 people at the end of 2008. Including the latest job cuts, the company has reduced its newspaper workforce by more than 1,000 employees since 2006.The company announced that it was suspending its quarterly dividend.

Federated Department Stores Inc. expects to cut 318 jobs when it closes a Kaufmann's outlet at a suburban Pittsburgh mall. Federated that it would trim 185 jobs with the closing of a Macy's at the Ross Park Mall and 368 with the closing of a Kaufmann's at South Hills Village.

Seagate Technology announced it plans lay off 10% of its U.S. work force, or about 800 people, in response to economic turmoil. Layoffs will affect a broad range of departments, including research and development.

Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. announced the closing of its Gold Shield Inc. facility in Fontana, California, which manufactures custom open-molded fiberglass parts. Employees were notified in July of the impending closure. Recreational vehicle industry pressures necessitated closure of the Fontana facility. The Fontana plant will be closed on or about September 28, 2007, and Fleetwood currently intends to make this property available for sale.

Lannett Company, Inc. approved a restructuring plan for its wholly owned unit Cody Laboratories. It has been unable to sell the Cody API business as an ongoing operation and now intends to sell the equipment and real estate used by the Cody API business and to have Cody Labs cease all operations. It will cut all remaining 70 positions at Cody Labs and expects all of this will be substantially completed by September 30.

AmerisourceBergen Corp. is shutting down its compounding pharmacy business, Illinois-based PharMEDium, by the end of 2020 in a move that will impact about 1,000 employees in four states. Valley Forge-based AmerisourceBergen, a wholesale pharmaceutical distribution and services company with annual revenues of just under $180 billion, acquired PharMEDium - a maker of ready-to-use compounded sterile preparations - in 2015 for $2.6 billion. PharMEDium has compounding facilities in Dayton, New Jersey; Cleveland; Mississippi; Sugar Land, Texas; and Memphis, Tennessee. Compounding pharmacies make drug formulas that are specially tailored to patients when commercially available drugs do not meet their needs. In May 2019, a federal judge issued a permanent injunction blocking the Memphis plant, PharMEDium's most active, from manufacturing activities after the Food and Drug Administration had issued numerous warnings for safety violations that were not addressed by PharMEDium. At that time, the company ceased operations at its Mississippi facility. Under the injunction, its Texas and New Jersey facilities were required to hire an independent expert to ensure compliance with the law. Production at PharMEDium's North Jersey plant was stopped last month. The status of its Texas plant could not immediately be determined.

Wells Fargo & Co. cut more than 3,000 mortgage jobs this summer. The company said that Wells Fargo expects a 30% drop in mortgage volume in the third quarter. Wells estimates originations this period will dip to about $80 billion from $112 billion in the second quarter.

Nielsen Co. announced plans to lay off 117 workers in July 2008 at its global technology centre in Oldsmar, Florida. The company employs 1,700 employees at this facility. The company will have to forgo the tax incentives it received to build the centre if it decides to lay off the workers. Nielsen also plans to reduce another 170 jobs.

Abercrombie & Fitch announced for the year 2014, the company plans to open 4 additional stores in China, including a mall-based A&F store in Chengdu and preparing for an accelerated rollout for both brands in 2015. For 2014, the company plans to open 2 additional Hollister stores in Japan, 1 at LaLaport Tokyo Bay and the other in Kobe, and it sees significant growth opportunity, given iearly success. During 2014, the company expects to open 15 full-priced international stores, including a small number of A&F mall-based stores. The company also now plan to open 8 to 10 international and U.S. outlet stores during the year. The company expects to close between 60 and 70 stores in the U.S. during the fiscal year through natural lease expirations.

Safeway Inc. announced that it will close 26 underperforming stores by year's end, including nine Tom Thumb stores in Dallas-Fort Worth. It will also shutter 16 Randalls stores in Houston and one in Austin. That will leave Safeway with 62 stores in Dallas-Fort Worth, 36 in Houston and 14 in Austin. It plans to remodel many of the remaining Texas stores to create so-called lifestyle centers, with higher-end products.

Computer Sciences Corporation announced that restructuring program, which is designed to streamline CSC's worldwide operation and leverage the increased use of lower cost resources, involves workforce reductions of approximately 4,300 employees during fiscal 2007, which began April 1, 2006, and approximately 700 employees in fiscal 2008. A majority of these reductions will occur in Europe, but plans will vary by country based on local legal requirements and consultation with works councils and employee representatives, as appropriate.
News Corp. has flagged job cuts after reporting a $5.9 billion first half net loss amid a grim economic climate.

State Street Corp. announced that it planned to slash another 1,800 jobs, or 9 percent of its work force, in a clear sign that weak markets continue to dog the Boston financial services company. The company will then lay off workers to meet its target of 1,800 fewer positions. The cuts follow the elimination of at least 575 jobs at State Street last year, plus 1,000 dismissals in Nashville and Jersey City, N.J., related to its recent acquisition of Deutsche Banks securities servicing group.
LTX Corp. announced that it would cut 153 jobs, or 25% of its work force.

General Motors Company has announced that it will close its Detroit-Hamtramck assembly plant, for four weeks beginning in June, for planned upgrades to prepare for a significant increase in the rate of Volt production, along with assembly of the 2013 Chevrolet Malibu midsize sedan. Already in tight supply, the number of Volts available for delivery to retail customers will be further restricted over the next three months before production resumes and the Volt and the Opel Ampera begin being exported to Europe and China. The 2011 Volt was launched in California, New York, Connecticut, Maryland, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, Texas, Virginia and Washington, D.C. The Volt will be available nationwide and in Europe, China and Canada by the end of this year. As a result of the plant upgrades, planned Volt and Ampera production capacity this year will increase to 16,000 units, including exports and a fleet of several hundred demonstration units sent to US dealers. In 2012, global production capacity is expected to be 60,000 vehicles with an estimated 45,000 to be delivered in the US. During the four-week shutdown the plant will complete some pre-scheduled upgrades, including the installation of new tools, equipment and overhead conveyor systems throughout the facility. This will prepare the plant for 2012 Volt and Ampera production and continue work on projects in preparation to launch the 2013 Malibu next year.

Russell Corp. announced that it would be permanently closing the doors on its carpet yarn operations at the Coosa River plant. The plant's closure marks the second time Wetumpka has been hit with negative news from the company. Russell's textile dyeing and finishing operations were eliminated last year, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs for employees.

Tailored Brands is also moving to cut $50 million in distribution, organizational, employee and occupancy costs in 2016. Those cost-cutting measures and store closures will cost between $45 million and $60 million in 2016.

CIGNA Corp. said it is laying off 135 to 150 employees in information technology about half of them in Connecticut as the company continues to pare expenses. The company has more than 3,400 IT employees including about 2,000 in Connecticut. The 135 to 150 cuts are in addition to the previously announced 3,900 terminations companywide, and arent part of a $98 million after-tax charge in the fourth quarter of last year.

The chairman of Textron Inc. said that nearly 20 percent of the company's top 150 executives didn't fare well in a recent performance review and could lose their jobs. Lewis Campbell said the review, which rated the 150 executives in color groups based on job performance, was completed as part of Textron's goal of managing its top executives much more aggressively. It was not clear whether the affected managers were concentrated in a specific division. A message left with a Textron spokeswoman was not immediately returned.

Hewlett-Packard Co. announced that it was shutting down its global operations unit to cut costs and would assign functions like logistics and procurement to its three business groups. The reorganization is the latest effort, to lower costs and make business groups more accountable for sales and profit. As part of the changes, expected to be completed by November, operations will be integrated into Hewlett-Packard's main business units, the Imaging and Printing Group, the Personal Systems Group, responsible for PC's, and the Technology Solutions Group, which handles server computers, storage, services and software.

280 people are to lose their jobs at Hewlett Packard. 220 are employees, while a further 60 are contractors. All work at the company's offices in Sandyford in Dublin. The job cuts follow a decision by one of the company's clients, Barclaycard, to move services closer to its customers in Portugal and Italy.

Maxim Integrated Products Inc. announced that it will stop developing certain standalone high-speed, high-resolution analog to digital converters. In particular, for a period of four years, Maxim will no longer develop standalone analog to digital converters having resolutions of 12 bits or higher and speeds of 65 MSPS and higher and with a principal purpose to convert an analog signal to a digital signal. This restriction does not include the use of A/D converters when embedded on the same die with a more comprehensive device, system or functionality.

Kindred Hospital Modesto, Modesto plans to close its doors early next year after efforts to sell the skilled-nursing facility were unsuccessful. The closure will result in job losses for 127 employees, including registered nurses, vocational nurses, nursing assistants and office personnel.
OraSure has announced that it plans to close its research and manufacturing plant in Beaverton by 2003 and move operations to Pennsylvania.
The layoffs announced by the Brunswick Group, affected the workforce of Brunswick Boat Group, cutting its staff by 6%.
Tesla (TSLA) cut several dozen sales team members in Chicago, Brooklyn, and Tampa. Ongoing job reductions are part of a shift to online ordering.
Keurig Green Mountain laid off approximately 130 employees in the week. Of those laid off, 40 were in Vermont and were primarily salaried and administrative workers.

Deluxe Corp. announced that it is closing its small-business call center in Colorado Springs and laying off the 225 employees who work there as it shifts work to its other call centers, beginning in January, 2010. The company announced that another Colorado Springs center with 300 employees who handle calls from consumers for Deluxe's Checks Unlimited check-printing unit is not affected. That unit laid off about 100 employees in 2009 after consolidating check-printing operations in Salt Lake City and Kansas City, Mo., reflecting effects of consumers' shift from personal checks to electronic payments.

Toys R Us Inc. is cutting nearly 1,200 Ohio jobs as it shutters stores across the state. This includes 79 employees at two Dayton-area locations: Miamisburg (37) and Beavercreek (42). The local stores are both set to permanently close on June 30, 2018. Their closures not only cost jobs, they leave two large retail spaces that will need to find new tenants. The struggling retail chain is closing its stores after facing the harsh headwinds of more competition in the toy sector from stores such as Walmart and Target, as well as online retailers such as Amazon.com.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. plans to lay off 98 employees in New York between July and October. The dismissals, which will happen between July 17 and October 29, are part of a third round of layoffs at the bank.
J.P. Morgan Chase Co. plans to complete its acquisition of Bank One Corporation corporate trust operations at the end of Octobe, 2003, and it will cut nearly half the Chicago unit's 525 workers.

Worthington Industries Inc. plans to close the 160,000-square-foot facility at 8911 Kelso Drive in Essex by the end of its current fiscal year, which ends May 31. The Essex facility is about 13 miles from the defunct Sparrows Point steel-making complex. Employees at the Worthington plant will have the opportunity to apply for job openings at other Worthington facilities. Severance and outplacement services will be provided to employees who will not continue with the company. In 2011, Worthington closed a metal framing plant on Bethlehem Boulevard in Edgemere. The closure resulted in 59 job cuts.
Exelis, Inc. cuts 21 jobs because of falling demand for defense-related products. The workers, mostly engineers, were given two weeks' notice and will receive severance pay and transition assistance.

PPG Industries Inc. has laid off 27 employees at its Springdale plant. The workers, all salaried chemists and technicians, were notified on January 24, 2006 that their jobs were being eliminated immediately. About 500 work at the facility, which produces coatings and resins.

Williams Companies Inc. said it will lay off 16 percent of the roughly 800 employees in its energy marketing and trading division because of the sector's slump. The company laid off 11 of its 86 London workers and cuts in Houston and at its Tulsa headquarters will come next week, spokeswoman Paula Hall-Collins said. The company employs about 50 energy trading workers in Houston and the remainder in Tulsa.

Ralph Lauren Corp. plans to shut its Polo store on New York's Fifth Avenue and cut some staff as it shifts more resources to e-commerce. The company will shutter other retail locations and upgrade its e-commerce system. Goods from the Fifth Avenue store will be sold at other Ralph Lauren stores in New York. The moves will result in $370 million in one-time expenses.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. announced that it would close its warehouse and distribution center at Lincoln Air Park between July and the close of this year, ending 160 jobs. Some of the workers - perhaps as few as 10 - may qualify for jobs at Goodyear's belt and hose manufacturing plant in Lincoln, but the others will lose their jobs. The company plans to open a new warehouse farther east. It declined to say where because final negotiations for the site are under way.
3Com Corp. announced that it will lay off approximately 3,000 workers over several quarters, in an attempt to reach profitability.
PNC Bank announced regulators that the branch at 3889 Military Trail is closed. That branch had $30 million in deposits on June 30, 2013. PNC Bank has five other branches in the city.

The A&P supermarket chain plans to close its Edison warehouse next month, cutting 230 union jobs. The Record has obtained a copy of a letter that a senior A&P executive wrote to the New Jersey Department of Labor outlining plans to permanently close the facility.
EI DuPont de Nemours & Co. will cut 1,500 jobs and consolidate manufacturing in its seeds unit in a move to lower operating costs by $100 million a year.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced that the Wal-Mart return center in south Bibb County will be closing by mid-September, affecting the jobs of 400 workers. The return operation here will be transferred to a third party and relocated near Spartanburg, S.C. The return center will cease operations on Sept. 13 of 2009.

Harrah's Entertainment Inc. announced that the Grand Casino Biloxi Hotel and Spa will re-open August 17, 2006 pending the receipt of all required regulatory approvals. Following a year-long renovation, the new land-based casino features more than 800 slot machines and 28 table games; a 500-room hotel; a 300-seat Grand Buffet, an Asian Cafe, L.B.'s Steakhouse and Starbucks coffee shop; and the full-service Bellissimo Spa.

PNC Financial Services Group Inc. plans to consolidate one branch in the Pittsburgh region within the next 90 days, its first local closure in 2016. The Bridgeville Trust branch, located at 456 Washington Ave. in Bridgeville, will be consolidated into the Great Southern Shopping Center office on Washington Pike, roughly a mile away, effective April 15.

InterDigital Inc. announced that it will lay off 100 employees, including some at its King of Prussia, as a result of a restructuring of its SlimChip business. The company expects the move will result in annualized pre-tax cost savings of approximately $33 million, of which 65% is cash-related.

General Motors Company announced it will close its fuel cell development office in Honeoye Falls, N.Y., and move operations to it global power train engineering headquarters in Pontiac by early 2013. GM said it notified about 220 affected salaried employees in Honeoye Falls on October 5. The majority of employees, who include engineers and technical experts, will have the option to relocate to Pontiac. GM will offer a severance package to those employees who choose not to transfer. The handful of employees not offered a move will have the chance to apply for other employment openings at GM. The Detroit automaker's lease expires in Honeoye Falls in early 2013 and fuel cell work will relocate into existing space in Pontiac.

General Motors Corporation's Argentine subsidiary announced that it was terminating the employment of 300 workers at its plant in General Alvear, Santa Fe. The company announced that it was reducing its workforce at the plant due to weak exports to Mexico, Brazil and Chile.

Ford Motor Co. ceased production at its casting plant in Windsor, Ontario, as part of the automaker's plan to exit the business of casting engine parts. The 500,000-square-foot plant employed about 450 people, making cylinder block castings for the company's 4.2-liter V-6 engines and crankshafts for the 4.2-liter, 5.4-liter V-8, 3.0-liter V-6, 4.6 liter V-8 and the 2.3-liter engines. The closure comes two days after thousands gathered for a rally in Windsor, located across the Detroit River from Detroit, to protest the loss of manufacturing jobs. Ford has identified 10 plants that it will close as part of a restructuring plan designed to shrink its production capacity to match reduced demand for its cars and trucks and return to profitability. The company has said it will close 16 facilities by 2012.

Amkor Technology, Inc. announced that its manufacturing facility in Kitakami, Japan has suffered relatively minor damage in earthquake. The Kitakami facility only provides services to a few Japan-based customers. The Kitakami facility is currently closed due to power supply interruptions and plans are underway to restore production capabilities at the site when power, gas and water supplies, and transportation systems are stabilized. The company analyze the situation and evaluate alternative sources of supply where appropriate.

Advanced Energy Industries Inc. announced that it will cut 200 jobs over the next nine months when it moves some of its manufacturing to China. The job cuts amount to 23% of the company's local work force and 12% of its staff worldwide.

General Motors, said it planned further job cuts in Europe as part of a radical overhaul of its business on the continent. GM vice chairman of product development, Bob Lutz, announced. He declined to say how many of GM's 60,000 jobs in Europe would be slashed, but company sources said the cuts would primarily affect administrative services. About half of its employees -some 32,000 - work for the German unit Opel. GM Europe, headquartered in Zurich, Switzerland but which largely comprises Opel, has been in the red since 1999.

About 1,080 call centre jobs are leaving Alberta following downsizing by Convergys Corporation, which will close its Edmonton call centre June 30. The Edmonton closure affects 400 people. The company is also closing its 280-employee Red Deer centre on June 30, and its Lethbridge operation, with 400 workers, at the end of August.
Ariba Inc. announced that in an effort to reduce spending, it will lay off 700 employees which represents approximately one third of its workforce.

Winnebago Industries Inc. is shutting down a factory in Charles City, Iowa and eliminating 270 jobs. The plant, which makes smaller units built on a van chassis, is expected to close in August, the news agency said. The company is blaming the weaker economy and fuel prices for the closure.

Regions Financial Corp. laid off at least seven workers at its local loan center in the Birmingham area as part of a minor work force adjustment. The bank recently announced plans to suspend its employees 401(k) matching contributions and pension plan accruals to avoid cutting 1,400 jobs.

Citizens Financial Group Inc. is laying off 900 employees. The company announced that the employees affected by the layoffs will be notified in the coming year. The cuts were being made across the commercial, retail and global transactions sectors.
Progress Energy has announced that it will lay off 80 to 100 telecommunications and information technology employees to cut costs.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced Three éˆ¥æ¥½mart Choiceéˆ?convenience stores (CVS) in Shenzhen that were run by the company were officially closed after a three years of operation. The company that such closure did not reveal failure of the CVS operation model, arguing that it is solely for testing in China and that the tests finish now. The company disclosed that with operation area being around 300 square meters, "Smart Choice" CVS focuses on food and daily necessities. Such operation model did not appear in the U.S. and was initiated in China.

HCA Inc. announced that it will shut down Northlake Medical Center on December 15, burdened by several years of declining inpatient volumes, high employee turnover, difficulty recruiting employees and financial losses at the Tucker, Ga., hospital. Northlake Medical Center's emergency department will close at noon on December 8. The hospital's 350 employees will get their regularly scheduled pay and benefits for 60 days. Employees, both part-time and full-time, also will receive severance pay and access to outplacement services.

FairPoint Communications, Inc. announced workforce restructuring actions that will result in a reduction of approximately 260 positions across the 17 states in which it operates, including the closing of its call center in South Burlington, Vermont. This action, combined with other headcount reductions over the past two years, approximates the level of voice line loss the company has experienced in that period.
Kellogg Company announced its plans to lay off 620 employees after it purchased the Keebler Foods Company. The majority of the lay offs will be Keebler employees.

Nearly 500 former May Department Stores Co. workers collected a severance check and lost their jobs as the retailer's operations were folded into those of Federated Department Stores Inc. The job losses are the latest chapter in Federated's takeover of St. Louis-based May. The local employees, who worked for May's corporate offices in downtown St. Louis or in the May Merchandise Co., either did not receive or refused job offers from Cincinnati-based Federated, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported.

Worthington Industries is laying off almost half of its workers in Skiatook. The company in Skiatook employs about 100 workers and the company cut 40 jobs. The company also said it reduced its workforce at its oil and gas equipment locations in Garden City, Kansas, and in Bremen and Wooster, Ohio, impacting approximately 205 employees.

Resolute Forest Products announced that it is halting production on its last paper machine at its mill in Fort Frances on January 31, 2014. Resolute blames the shutdown on market conditions and says it will be laying off 150 workers in the northwestern Ontario town - leaving about 60 others to manage operations. The machine that produces specialty printing papers will be stopped on Jan. 31, 2014.

US Airways Group Inc. plans to lay off 471 more pilots by May to offset rising fuel costs and continued weakness in the airline industry. The planned cuts, 326 by Jan. 7 and 145 by May, would mark a 30 percent reduction in the number of pilots since the 2001 terrorist attacks, the Air Line Pilots Association union said. US Airways also plans to furlough 915 flight attendants by December, although most of the departures are expected to be voluntary. The airline has already laid off nearly 2,700 flight attendants of the 10,000 employed at the time of the terrorist attacks.

Norfolk Southern Corp. planned to close its office building in Roanoke, relocating the functions handled there to Atlanta or Norfolk. The move affects about 500 employees currently working in marketing, accounting, information technology and other departments. Norfolk Southern said they will have the option to relocate with their positions. Roanoke is the headquarters for Norfolk Southernéˆ¥æªš Virginia Division. The company said it will continue operating a local switching yard and locomotive and car maintenance facilities at Shafferéˆ¥æªš Crossing and a locomotive overhaul and rebuilding facility in its East End Shops. About 1,700 people now work for Norfolk Southern in Roanoke.

Abbott Laboratories is understood to be planning a meeting with staff on December 4, 2007 afternoon to outline details of the cuts. The company employs more than 3,500 people in six plants around Ireland and is believed to be planning significant redundancies. The Galway plant in Mervue is expected to be the focus of the lay-offs.

General Motors Corp. has laid off about 100 workers at its Parma parts plant located near Cleveland. The company says hundreds of other workers will face temporary furloughs in January. About half of the Parma Metals Center will remain shut down for another three weeks after the company's traditional two-week holiday shutdown period ends Jan. 5. About 600 people will be affected at any given time.
General Mills Inc. will close a flour mill it has operated in Johnson City for 70 years, move the production to other facilities and leave 26 people without jobs.

TeleTech Holdings Inc. presented a downsizing plan, which envisages dismissing 133 employees, out of the total 2,576 in Spain. The plan will affect the personnel at the company's plants in Barcelona, Madrid and Oviedo. The employees in Toledo and Valencia are not in jeopardy of losing their jobs.

Mead Westvaco Corporation announced that it will close its general consumer packaging operations in Newark, Delaware. The facility converts paper and paperboard into printed packages and is part of MeadWestvaco's packaging segment. The company expects to close the facility by late April 2003.

Acxiom Corp. announced that it will cut 265 positions, 140 of them in Arkansas. The workforce reduction, in addition to other targeted expense cuts, will position Acxiom to deliver improved financial results. The cut represents about 3.7% of the company's workforce.
Kulicke and Soffa Inds. announced that it has laid off 700 employees.

Rue21 announced it was closing about 400 stores. That includes its Bellis Fair space, which is in the Macy's wing, as well as a location in Everett. The clothing company is currently having a closing-store sale. Hundreds of its stores, including 11 in Washington, will remain open.

Sprint Nextel Corp. announced that it is cutting about 75 mainly sales and marketing jobs from a unit that provides network equipment to other telecommunications companies. The cuts come as the company seeks to serve some customers more with online services instead of direct sales. About two-thirds of the laid-off workers were from the North Supply unit in Gardner, which is south of Kansas City. The remainder of the workers are from other parts of the country.

Google Inc. announced that it will shut down Postini services at the end of 2013 and migrate Postini customers to Google Apps. Starting September 20, Retarus is offering Google/Postini customers a free, automated and secure switchover to their Managed E-Mail Services. Retarus' Managed E-Mail Services fulfill all business requirements, including those concerning data security, data protection and legal compliance. Furthermore, Retarus' Managed E-Mail Services clearly surpass Postini's mail service standards. Five years after Google took over Postini services, the company has now announced that it will discontinue them at the end of 2013 and no contract renewals will be accepted after October 31, 2012. Postini customers will be directed to a new service which is currently being implemented as a part of Google Apps. Companies will be able to retain their usual functions and tried-and-tested configurations, including user-specific settings, when migrating from Postini to Retarus' Managed E-Mail Services. Retarus transfers customized settings upon agreement with the customer and configures Managed E-Mail Services according to their requirements. Users will be able to continue using their mail services without any problems and benefit from additional advantages offered by Retarus. These include convenient administration, detailed monitoring, a web-based multilingual administration portal with comprehensive configuration possibilities as well as round-the-clock direct support from the service provider's qualified specialists in Germany and eleven international subsidiaries. In addition, Retarus Managed E-Mail Services provide considerable advantages as regards data security and compliance. Customers always retain control over the country-specific regulations to be observed and whether the data processed in Retarus data centers within the European Union is transferred to the United States or solely processed outside of the US. Retarus also offers a series of solutions for the secure processing of emails.

Alcoa Inc. announced that it is laying off 200 of the 600 workers at its Intalco aluminum smelter and cutting production in half because of high electricity costs. The Pittsburgh-based company initially planned to close the plant near Bellingham on Sept. 30, but delayed the decision until Wednesday to give elected officials and others in the region time to work to mitigate a rate increase from the BPA.
AT&T Wireless Services Inc. records $47 million charge in second quarter 2003 related to restructuring costs Including reduction of 1500 employees.

Williams Cos. stock soared after the company disclosed more of its continuing plan to cut its staggering debt, which will mean fewer jobs at energy giant. At the beginning of 2002, the company employed about 12,000 people. The work force, currently at about 9,300, is expected to be slashed to less than 6,000 by year's end as the company continues to sell pieces of its business.

About 180 workers throughout Western New York received pink slips from Verizon Communications Inc. most of them repair and maintenance staff. The layoffs, part of a 2,400 cutback statewide, were the first for blue-collar phone workers since World War II, perhaps even before that, company and union officials said.
Standard Register Co. plans to close facilities and reduce its workforce as it struggles to deal with mounting losses and looming debt.

A&P announced 25 separate store closings late last year. United Food and Commercial Workers Local 1262, Clifton, N.J., confirmed that Pathmark stores located in Gillette, Hillsboro, Livingston, Middletown, North Hackensack, South Plainfield and Whippany, N.J., would close. UFCW Local 1500 in New York conformed closures of Pathmark stores in Commack, Brooklyn and Hartsdale, N.Y. Additional stores set to close include Waldbaums locations in Greenburgh, Port Chester and Carmel, N.Y.; and A&P banner stores in Flanders, N.J., Barnegat, N.J., Manville, N.J., and New Rochelle, N.Y.

Cisco has confirmed 225 of its 6,000 reported global layoffs hit its Research Triangle Park campus. The number represents nearly 4% of company's 5,500 headcount in RTP. The company is in the process of expanding and adding 550 jobs to RTP - a plan that continues, in spite of layoffs.

Delta Woodside Industries Inc. announced that it would cut 400 jobs, or more than a quarter of its work force, to reduce costs amid oversupply and increased competition from imports. The company said it planned to close a cotton mill in Piedmont, S.C., affecting about 361 jobs. Salaries and positions at other plants will be cut, Delta said. Delta will have 1,100 employees, down from 2,000 three years ago, and four plants, down from seven, after the restructuring. The company has been streamlining operations in anticipation of the expiration of import quotas in January 2005.

Hanesbrands Inc. is eliminating jobs at its headquarters in North Carolina and closing a distribution center, moves that affect 440 workers. The company reported that the 200 layoffs at the headquarters affect workers in finance, human resources, sales and marketing and supply chain management. Shutting down the distribution center affects 240 workers, including 40 third-shift workers immediately.

CSX Corp. announced that 132 workers at its Buffalo rail yard will be laid off by the end of this month. The company said that it would end its major switching operations at Frontier Yards by the end of May. CSX officials told union leaders that about 20% of the yard's employees would lose their jobs as the company eliminates jobs because of a decline in shipping volume caused by the economic downturn. CSX says more than 330 workers will continue to be based at the facility. About half of the work being done at the Frontier Yards is to be moved to other CSX facilities in western New York.

Wachovia Corp. plans to close a string of branches in older suburbs and city districts, while opening new offices in wealthier or improving neighborhoods. The bank expects to shut its Coatesville, Clifton Heights, Five Points (Levittown), Lower Chichester, and Township Line (Drexel Hill) branches on December 6, 2006. It has previously announced it planned to close two Philadelphia branches, at Front Street and Allegheny Avenue and at Germantown and Lehigh Avenues, that day; two branches in Allentown will also be shut.Wachovia is planning to open new branches in Concordville, Delaware County; Warrington, Bucks County; and Audubon, Montgomery County. The bank had previously announced plans for branches in University City and Parkside, both sites of new commercial development in West Philadelphia. Wachovia is also considering new branches in the gentrifying Northern Liberties and Brewerytown sections of Philadelphia.

Dow Chemical Co. to announce possible layoffs at the chemical producer's Freeport complex in Texas. More than 4,000 contract workers are currently employed at the plant. The company said the layoffs will occur in stages from 15 December through 5 January.

Pennsylvania Real Estate Investment Trust announced closure of the 118,000 square foot JCPenney store at its Exton Square Mall. PREIT looks forward to incorporating the JCPenney building into its planned redevelopment of the mall which is expected to follow the recapture of an existing Kmart location, ideally located with extensive frontage along heavily traveled Route 100 in Exton, Pennsylvania. Exton Square Mall is located in Chester County, whose exceptional demographics include the hige incomes in Pennsylvania. According to demographic data, 37.5% of households in the trade area exceed $100,000, which significantly exceeds the state average. Further demonstrating the strength of the market, average home values in the trade area are 75% higher than the state average.

Staples Inc. is eliminating 60 jobs in Phoenix. The office superstore chain is cutting the jobs at a delivery operations center in Phoenix. The company has 23 stores in the Phoenix metro area. The company reported the layoffs to the state of Arizona under the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act.

Navistar announced that it will cease all engine production at its plant in Melrose Park, Ill., by the second quarter of fiscal 2018. The company will continue the facility's transformation into Navistar's technical center, including truck and engine testing and validation as well as used truck sales and reconditioning, continuing the process that started in 2010. The majority of engines produced at Melrose Park are medium duty 9/10 liter engines used in Internationalåº?Class 6 and 7 vehicles, for which alternative engine options are currently offered in all applications. Once completed, the cessation of engine manufacturing at Melrose Park is expected to affect about 170 employees and reduce Navistar's operating costs by approximately $12 million annually. The company will take an approximate $43 million charge as a result of this action, including approximately $8 million of cash related charges. A significant portion of the hourly employees at Melrose Park are retirement-eligible. Assistance and opportunities for retraining will be offered.

Lowe's Cos. Inc. plans to close all 99 Orchard Supply Hardware store locations nationwide by the end of this year after reassessing its company priorities. The company which also owns Lowe's Hardware Stores, chose to shutter the locations of its subsidiary in an effort to focus on the main Lowe's hardware store brand. The closures will affect locations at 111 South Orlando Ave. in Winter Park and 7603 Turkey Lake Road in Bay Hill, as well as a planned new facility under construction at Orlando Fashion Square mall that would have taken part of a former Sears location. Store closing sales for the San Jose, Calif.-based company will start Aug. 23 and operations will wind down until the end of the year. 4,300 total associates will be displaced by the closures. The Bayhill Plaza location, which opened Feb. 14, 2017, was the area's first Orchard Supply and has 45 employees. Employees will receive job placement help and there are opportunities for some to receive severance pay. Lowe's has accounted for $390 million to $475 million related to lease obligations and severance pay for employees in its estimates for next quarter.

Xilinx Inc. announced that it will eliminate about 250 jobs as part of a company reorganization meant to improve operating performance. The job cuts, which are expected to be completed by the end of the next fiscal year, will adversely impact Xilinx's first-quarter operating expenses.
AutoNation Inc. announced plans to cut 1,300 jobs and sell underperforming stores as part of a plan to reduce its costs by $100 million a year.

Motorola Inc. is slashing its work force - again - in a move the company says will usher in a return to profitability after a lengthy losing streak. The struggling technology giant announced that it is trimming 9,400 jobs, or more than 8 percent of its work force, in the latest of a series of sweeping cuts. The cell phone and computer chip maker said the move, combined with semiconductor plant closings and other restructuring measures, will result in about $1 billion in annual cost savings. Company executives said they expect to turn a profit next year. The latest cuts are to be made over the course of the next year. Motorola's semiconductor operations will see 4,000 jobs eliminated, while 1,300 jobs will be cut from its equipment manufacturing businesses. Another 4,100 cuts will be distributed companywide.

RadioShack Corp. laid off workers at its corporate headquarters on September 6, 2012 morning as the company continues to reduce costs following a second-quarter loss. Job cuts were mostly concentrated at the riverfront headquarters, where the company said earlier this year it had about 1,200 workers.
VeriFone Holdings Inc. announced that it laid off approximately 100 employees in December in response to weakened demand for the San Jose, Calif.-based company's products.

Delta Air Lines Inc. plans to cut an unspecified number of pilot jobs through a program that would give pilots an incentive to retire. Under the terms of the proposal, active pilots who have met certain age and length-of-service metrics would be eligible to participate in the program.

Macy's Inc. is closing at least 11 new locations. Nine of those stores, however, had already closed in 2019. Macy's confirmed to the Business Courier that it's closing its Northgate Mall store in Cincinnati, with a clearance sale beginning this month and running for up to three months. A final closing date has not yet been set. Macy's closed nine stores in 2019: Charleston Town Center, Charleston, S.C.; Casper Eastridge, Casper, Wyo.; Redmond Town Center, Redmond, Wash; Sunnyvale Town Center, Sunnyvale, Calif; Macy's Furniture Gallery, Westside Pavilion, Los Angele; Glendale Galleria, Indianapolis; Swansea, Mass; Tysons Galleria, McLean, Va; Nanuet Mall, Nanuet, N.Y.
