Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. announced that it will close a plant that makes heart disease and diabetes medicine in western Puerto Rico, eliminating about 400 jobs. The closure, the result of reduced demand for the medication, will occur in stages and be completed at the end of 2008.
Omnicare Inc. eliminated the jobs of about 50 people at the headquarters of NeighborCare, the Baltimore company it bought last month, a source confirmed.

G&K Services Inc. announced that, it reduced its North American workforce by approximately 340 positions and also eliminated approximately 120 currently open positions. These steps further adjust the company's cost structure in response to lower customer volumes and the expectation of continued weakness in near-term economic conditions. The company noted that, these actions will not impact the company's continued focus on providing excellent service to customers.
Federal-Mogul Corp. has announced that it plans to close its plants in Orangeburg and Summerton as it is consolidating its operations to Mexico due to lower demand.

FTI Consulting, Inc. plans to close three offices and cut about 150 jobs this quarter, taking a $25 million charge as a result. FTI Consulting did not disclose which offices would close. The company said the affected locations will be disclosed as they are consolidated in coming weeks. These actions are intended to eliminate certain redundancies resulting from acquisitions completed over the last two years, to better align capacity with expected demand and to provide for appropriate levels of administrative support, but in a more efficient manner. It expects the job cuts and office closings to be the only reductions made this year.

WellPoint Inc. is eliminating approximately 1,500 positions. This includes the elimination of more than 900 open positions. The approximately 600 associates affected by the layoff will receive both severance pay and outplacement assistance in accordance with WellPoint's policies.

Amazon plans to layoff 36 employees at its Jersey City office, while transferring another 41 workers to Newark and New York City effective May 31. The company plans to work with the employees whose roles were eliminated to find other jobs within Amazon.

General Motors (GM) has announced that its plant in St Petersburg, Russia, will completely stop production for almost two months as a result of falling demand for the models manufactured at the facility. The company has taken the decision to halt production at the facility between 23 March and 14 May in order to rebalance inventories for vehicles manufactured at the facility with demand. Workers at the plant will be paid during the downtime, in line with Russian labor legislation.

Due to a prolonged strike, Delta Air Lines Inc.'s regional-carrier division, Comair Inc., will layoff 200 of its 1,350 pilot jobs and cut its fleet by 14% or about 17 planes, in an effort to decrease costs.

GenOn Energy, Inc. has put power plants in Elrama, Washington County, and in New Castle on its list of eight plants to shut down by May 2015 because of environmental regulations. Elrama, a 460-megawatt plant, will be deactivated in June. The 330-megawatt New Castle plant is expected to close in April 2015. According to the company, the eight plants in Pennsylvania, Ohio and New Jersey represent about 13% of its generating capacity, or 3,140 megawatts in the wholesale market. One megawatt can power about 800 homes. But the plants, seven of which burn coal, don't generate enough profit to cover costs of complying with new air pollution rules.
Wendy's International Inc. announced that it will close 15 to 18 underperforming Baja Fresh stores, resulting in a charge of $17 to $18 million.

Intel announced that it will close a small production facility in Jerusalem and transfer most of the 170 people who work there to a factory 40 miles away in Kiryat Gat. Itéˆ¥æªš the latest step in a broad restructuring Intel announced in April designed to prepare the company for long-term decline in its core business: making microprocessors for PCs and laptops. Intel is eliminating 12,000 jobs by the middle of the next year through a mix of layoffs, buyouts and early retirement offers. Intel operates a research and development facility in Jerusalem that wonéˆ¥æª› be affected. Intel is closing a number of smaller outposts around the world, including a site in DuPont, Washington. The companyéˆ¥æªš largest operations are in Oregon, and though Intel is cutting jobs locally it does not appear likely to shut down any of its facilities here.

The New York Times Company has laid off at least 18 newsroom employees in the latest round of cutbacks driven by the newspaper's financial woes. In October, the newspaper said it would trim 100 jobs from its newsroom, leaving about 1,150 reporters and editors. Management hoped to avoid layoffs with buyout packages, but only 73 union and nonunion workers accepted. The company said that still expects to reach its goal of 100 newsroom job cuts by year's end.

CONSOL Energy Inc. has issued notice under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN) of a lay off at its Fola Operations near Bickmore, W. Va. It is expected that the layoffs will occur during a 14-day period beginning at 12:01 a.m., on Sunday, February 7, 2010. Approximately 104 workers at the Little Eagle Coal Company and 378 at the Fola Coal Company may be affected by the layoff. The company attributed the idling at Fola Operations to the appeal of its approved permits to mine brought by the Ohio Valley Environmental Coalition (OVEC). Subsequent to that appeal, Judge Robert C. Chambers, of the United States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia, Huntington Division, recently issued an order suspending Fola Coal Company's Clean Water Act Section 404 permit for the Ike Fork portions of Fola Operations effective January 23, 2009. Without this permit, neither Fola Coal Company nor Little Eagle Coal Company can satisfy the required specifications of its coal sales contracts.
Merrill Lynch & Co. has announced that it will move all Nasdaq trading to its New York headquarters and shut down the office in Jersey City, laying off an unspecified number of employees.
The Kimberly Clark mill in Conway intends to fire 140 employees, or 20 percent of the mill's total workforce, within the next six to nine months, because the mill has become more efficient.
General Electric will lay off 44 employees at its Shreveport plant by the end of the month due to economic slowdown that has led to a lower demand for their product.
Adobe Systems Inc. has announced plans to slash its global workforce by 9%, eliminating some 680 full-time positions, in a bid to realign its costs in connection with its 2010 operating plan.

C-COR.net Corp. will close its recently acquired upstate New York cable television products plant and eliminate 250 jobs. The State College, Pa. -based company acquired the former Philips Broadband Networks plant in September. C-Cor officials said manufacturing will cease in February and the rest of the operation will be shut down by July. The company had planned to maintain its suburban Syracuse operations after merging with Philips, but a prolonged slump in sales changed their minds.

The Black & Decker Corp. will close its Easton plant, eliminating 1,300 jobs and leaving the toolmaker with virtually no manufacturing presence in its home state. Most of the Maryland jobs will move to Mexico; others will shift to Brazil and Fayetteville, N.C. The Towson, Md. -based company's layoffs could begin as early as January. The plant has 750 full-time employees and 550 contract workers. It produces the company's DeWalt tools and has been in operation since 1974. The company employs about 1,150 people at its headquarters and about 250 workers at a plant in Hampstead. About half of the toolmaker's nearly 23,000 employees worldwide are based in the United States.

Electronic Data Systems Corp. announced that it plans to cut 3,000 to 4,000 jobs in the second half of 2006. The cuts, intended to make the company more efficient, fall within the range of 2004 forecast for layoffs of 15,000 to 20,000. But the company had not anticipated the new cuts earlier this year. As of April, EDS had about 117,000 employees worldwide, including 7,100 in the Dallas area.

Bob Evans Farms, Inc. announced that it is closing 27 Bob Evans Restaurants. Twenty-one of the restaurants are owned and six are leased locations. The owned locations closed April 23, 2016 and April 24, 2016, and the remaining leased locations are expected to close during fiscal year 2017.

Pfizer Inc. laid off 50 employees earlier this month, and is cutting between 50 and 150 people in two-week cycles through the rest of the summer. The company has announced that it plans to transfer up to 70% of the Ann Arbor employees to other company locations.

The New York Post reported that Time Inc. will lay off 540 employees, while The New York Times said the company was looking to cut $100 million in costs. It is only the latest in a series of cutbacks among the major U.S. magazine publishers. The recession has put a huge dent in advertising budgets, and the toll of closings and layoffs continued to rise this month.

Dana Corp. announced it will eliminate a total of approximately 800 jobs at one Canadian and three Australian plants in 2006. By December 2006, approximately 500 jobs will be eliminated at Dana's Structural Products plant in Thorold, Ont. This reduction results from the expiration of a supply agreement for truck frames. With the remaining work force of 180 people, this plant will continue to serve as a stamping operation supplying multiple Dana facilities. By mid 2006, the company will also cut as many as 300 jobs from its Traction Products facilities in Salisbury, South Australia; Cheltenham, Victoria; and Yennora, New South Wales.

L Brands Co. plans to close around 250 Victoria's Secret stores in North America over the next several months. The company expects to close more stores in 2021 and beyond. Further, it plans to close 50 Bath Works stores in the U.S. and one in Canada. According to the company, the decision is to strengthen the foundation of Victoria's Secret, which is being separated as a standalone company, to manage through the current crisis of coronavirus pandemic.
Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. announced late June that it will lay off 230 employees due to economic reasons.

Umpqua Holdings will close 27 branches by the end of 2014 as part of its integration of Sterling Financial in Spokane, Wash. The closures will begin in September 2014. Customer accounts will be automatically transferred to the nearest branch location. The closures include 13 Umpqua and 14 Sterling branches, located across the $11.8 billion-asset company's operations. The list includes 13 branches in Washington, seven in Oregon and seven in California.

LCA-Vision Inc. reported earnings results for the third quarter of 2009. The company posted a third- quarter net loss of $19.9 million or $1.07 per share, compared to a net loss of $4.7 million or 25 cents per share, in the third- quarter 2008. The company also announced that it would close 10 of its 71 U.S. centers and reduce its work force by 15%.
Northrop Grumman Corp. announced that it is laying off 490 employees. It said that all the layoffs will be complete by late june.

JDSU has announced that it will come out of concentrated photovoltaics (CPV) manufacturing business in the absence of an encouraging solar power market. The company, however, did not rule out reentering the sector in the future.

Manitowoc Co. Inc. has cut deep into its workforce and plans to eliminate about 40% of the jobs in its largest division, which builds construction cranes. The company announced demand across businesses continues to be weak, especially in the cranes segment, which is causing it to operate at production levels well below its capacity.

Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. announced that the plant was no longer viable due to intense international competition. 150 jobs are to be lost following the closure of a plant. This plant has been in operation since the early 1970s and was acquired by the US-based ADM in 1990. The closure of the plant will begin immediately and will take over a month to complete.

Federal regulators have launched an informal inquiry into an Eastman Kodak Co. financial restatement that trimmed the photography company's profits by $105 million to fix accounting errors mainly in taxes and pensions over the last two years. Kodak, which is undergoing a dramatic overhaul as the digital-imaging revolution sidelines chemical-based film, said the Securities and Exchange Commission indicated the inquiry should not be construed as a sign that any legal violations have occurred.

The company is shutting film and other manufacturing operations around the world and eliminating 22,000 to 25,000 jobs by mid 2007. That will likely lower its global work force to less than 50,000, down from 75,100 in 2001 and a peak of 145,300 in 1988.

Yahoo! said it plans to close down its research centre in Grenoble, southeastern France, thus cutting 78 jobs. The group will reorganise its research teams at four major centres, in the USA, London, Taiwan and India. According to the plan presented to the works council, all the employees will be offered a transfer to sites in the UK, Switzerland, Spain or the USA. At the beginning of the year, Yahoo axed 40 jobs in Paris.

Fannie Mae has eliminated 20 public affairs positions in its regional offices and created seven new ones elsewhere in an attempt to place an emphasis on the shift from lobbying operations to business communications. The posts that were eliminated had operated on a regional basis in five offices, supporting Fannie Mae's grassroots political operations across the country to advance the company's legislative agenda. The laid-off employees will be eligible to reapply for the new positions.

L Brands, Inc. announced that it expects to deliver approximately $400 million in annualized cost reductions through its profit improvement plan for Victoriaéˆ¥æªš Secret and actions to decentralize and streamline shared corporate and other functions. The company expects to generate these annualized cost reductions through the following: A reduction of its home office headcount by approximately 15%, or about 850 associates, following completion of the previously announced review of its home office organizations in order to achieve meaningful reductions in overhead expenses and decentralize significant shared corporate and other functions and services in support of creating standalone companies. The company is providing a comprehensive benefits package for its departing associates, including severance, continuing access to health benefits and outplacement services, among other support. Reducing Victoriaéˆ¥æªš Secret store selling costs through changes in management structure and the labor model. Executing its previously announced plan to close 250 Victoriaéˆ¥æªš Secret stores in 2020 while also negotiating with landlords for ongoing rent relief. Actively working to reduce operating losses in the company-owned businesses in the U.K. and China. In the U.K., the company entered into éˆ¥æ¥²ight Administrationéˆ?in June in order to restructure lease agreements and explore the sale of the business to a joint venture or franchise partner. The company subsequently signed Heads of Terms with a major fashion retailer and is in an exclusive period of negotiation. In China, the company closed its unprofitable store in Hong Kong, is close to resolution to either close or restructure lease terms on other unprofitable stores and has implemented a significant overhead expense reduction plan.
Pope & Talbot announced on January 17 that it would temporarily lay off 250 employees due to poor conditions in the lumber market and the increase of energy costs.
Dow Jones & Co. has announced that it may cut an unspecified number of jobs, as the company seeks to counter lower ad sales by cutting costs.

Consol Energy Inc. will eliminate about 100 coal mining jobs from its 84 Mine in Washington County, by the end of the year because there is a substantial amount of rock where mining activity is occurring. Consol Energy's Eighty-Four Mining Co. subsidiary notified the state Department of Labor and Industry on Oct. 17 that the layoffs will begin Dec. 18 and continue for the remainder of the year.

New Albertsons Inc. has announced plans to close its Temple City store at 5595 Rosemead Blvd. The closure date is slated for April 2009. Albertsons has also announced the closing of stores in Rancho Cucamonga, Lancaster, Lakewood, Cathedral City and San Diego. The chain has 278 stores in Southern California.

Wachovia Corp. is expected to close the World Savings branch in Manchester. The closure is expected on March 12. The company will consolidate the branch with its branch on Colonial Drive in Manchester. No employees are expected to be laid off because of the closure.

The Latest on the Starbucks' plan to close stores Tuesday for anti-bias training. A Starbucks worker cordoned off a line of customers at the company's famous Pike Place Market location in Seattle as employees prepared to receive anti-bias training. The Seattle store, commonly referred to as the original Starbucks, stopped letting people in at 1 p.m. Tuesday. The company was holding training sessions at its 8,000 U.S. stores following an outcry over the arrest of two black men last month for sitting in a Philadelphia Starbucks without buying anything.

Arch Coal Inc. announced on June 21, 2012 it would lay off about 750 workers in the Kentucky, Virginia and West Virginia coalfields. The bulk of the cuts by Arch Coal Inc., almost 600, are in Kentucky. The disappearance of high-paying mining work heightened anxiety in hardscrabble Kentucky towns where officials worried declining demand for coal would result in leaner budgets and more people on unemployment rolls. The layoffs come amid forecasts that the share of U.S. electricity coming from coal will fall below 40% for the year the lowest level since the government began collecting data in 1949. Four years ago, it was 50%. By the end of this decade, it is likely to be near 30%. The job losses come as utilities increasingly switch from coal to natural gas, which has become cheaper as supplies grow. Natural gas' advantages over coal include producing fewer emissions of toxic chemicals and gases that contribute to climate change. From Kentucky courthouses to Congress, officials blamed tougher environmental rules for coal's woes and the resulting job losses.
Dow Chemical Co. has announced it would eliminate 110 jobs, approximately 3.6 percent of the work force, at its Michigan Operations plant as part of a cost-cutting plan.

OfficeMax Inc. has decided to close a customer call center in suburban Cleveland, affecting more than 200 workers. Employees at the facility in Mentor learned that their last day would be Oct. 31. The company says it will provide severance packages to workers who are eligible. OfficeMax will continue to operate four other call centers, in Illinois, Wyoming and Virginia.

Hospira Inc. announced details regarding Project Fuel, a multi-phased initiative to improve the company's margins and fuel its growth. Project Fuel will capitalize on the company's potential to increase shareholder value and improve operational efficiency by optimizing its product line, evaluating non-strategic assets and streamlining its organizational structure. In conjunction with these actions, which are slated to occur over the next 24 months, Hospira expects to reduce its global workforce by approximately 10% and deliver annual cost savings of approximately $110 million to $140 million. The net projected reduction associated with these collective actions represents approximately 10% of the company's global workforce, with the majority of reductions occurring in the next 12 months. In connection with these actions, Hospira estimates it will incur total pre-tax charges in the range of $140 million to $160 million, of which approximately $90 million to $100 million will be incurred during 2009. For the year 2009, the company estimates approximately $30 million of non-cash costs is related to various potential asset write-downs.

Movie Gallery Inc.'s announced that it plans to close its remaining namesake and Hollywood Video stores brings a bittersweet win for Dallas-based Blockbuster Inc. It leaves Blockbuster as the only national movie-rental store chain - but in a fast-changing industry combating new technologies and new competitors. While Movie Gallery stores are mostly in rural locations, Hollywood Video stores compete head to head with Blockbuster. Employees in five of the company's 16 stores in small North Texas towns said May 07, 2010 would be their last day. The other stores said they've been told remaining stores will also close soon.

Meredith Corp. announced that, it will eliminate 250 jobs, or about 7% of its work force, as the recession cuts into advertising revenue at its magazines and television stations. About 100 of the eliminated jobs are in Des Moines, where the company's headquarters is located. The remaining 150 are elsewhere in the country. The company said, it will close Country Home magazine and relocate art and editorial jobs of ReadyMade magazine from Berkeley, Calif., to Des Moines. Creative positions at Parents.com in New York will also relocate to Des Moines. The company said, magazine has about 1.2 million subscribers. Closing it accounts for about 20 of the jobs cut in Des Moines. Another 20 positions in New York will be eliminated.

Agere Systems Inc. will cut 110 jobs between now and the middle of the year 2006. It's unclear whether the jobs are at its headquarters and research facilities in the Lehigh Valley or at the company's other offices in California, Colorado and overseas. The job cuts are part of a plan that the company announced in October to consolidate operations and improve profitability.

United Technologies Corp. announced that more than 100 workers have been laid off from a northern Indiana plant that makes electronic components for heating and cooling control units. It cut the jobs of 112 hourly workers. But most of the layoffs at the plant about 20 miles southwest of Fort Wayne were voluntary.

Yahoo! Inc. will close before the end of the year 2008 its office in the Netherlands, with six employees. The activities, mainly search marketing, will be handled from London and Dublin. The closure is part of the company's global restructuring plan.

Unitedhealth Group Inc. announced that will lay off more than three dozen workers in Louisville next month, according to a filing with the state of Kentucky. A notice of the layoffs said 38 employees of Ingenix were told Aug. 21 that the job cuts would be effective by Oct. 20. The employees are located at an office at 301 N. Hurstbourne Parkway.

RSA Security Inc. has approved a plan to reorganize its structure which includes cutting 17 percent of its work force, or 200 workers and taking a related second quarter charge of $8 million to $10 million. 

The company also said it is forming three new product divisions comprised of engineering and product management teams focused on authentication, developer solutions/encryption and Web access management. The company's sales, marketing and general and administrative functions will continue to operate as separate groups serving the entire corporation.

ICU Medical disclosed that it will close its Vrable, Slovakia manufacturing facility and take a $3.4 million restructuring charge in fourth quarter 2015. The decision to close the Slovakian location will impact approximately 265 employees. Net cash outlays related to this action are expected to be approximately $3.3 million to $3.7 million, substantially all of which is expected to be paid for during fiscal 2016. The company will shift production from the Vrable facility to its facility in Ensenada, Mexico to take advantage of excess capacity there.
Toys R Us Inc. announced that it would lay off 100 people and would not seek to fill 200 vacant positions.

Macy's Inc. notified the state Jan. 6, 2017 that it would lay off 100 employees for its Oviedo Marketplace Store at 1400 Oviedo Marketplace Blvd. The layoffs will take effect starting March 6-19, 2017. The company, which has six stores in Central Florida, announced Jan. 4, 2017 that it was closing 68 stores, including five in Florida. The one in Oviedo Marketplace is the only one in Central Florida slated for closure. The company also has layoffs planned for a store in Sarasota, laying off 92 workers there, and another in Tampa, laying off 80 workers there. Both of those locations will close, as well.

Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. announced that it will axe 58 jobs at a bottling plant. Managers and shop floor staff in East Kilbride, Lanarkshire, face redundancy. Workers in the East Kilbride distribution operation face the sack as part of a drive to shed 170 jobs across the UK.

La-Z-Boy Inc. will lay off 850 workers as it reported a widening loss for its fiscal second quarter, hurt by a deteriorating economy and historically low customer confidence. The company will cut 850 workers, or about 10% of its work force, and expects between 15 and 20 dealer-owned stores to close in the next 90 to 120 days.

International Business Machines Corp. has made its first filing under the new New York state Worker Adjustment, Retraining and Notification law, or WARN. But it was a partial one. The notice said 274 workers in software applications at the Hudson Valley Research Park here will be laid off for 'economic reasons' effective April 27. Those job cuts are part of a larger 'resource action' IBM launched in its Systems and Technology Group. Other cuts were in technical posts involved in semiconductor production, the chief role of the East Fishkill complex.

In another economic blow to a south-central Kansas community that has lost thousands of jobs in recent years, about 200 employees at the Winfield plant of Newell Rubbermaid Inc. are being laid off. The plant, which has employed between 550 and 600 employees, was shut down.

A Pier 1 Imports Inc. shareholder wants the company to close between 250 and 300 underperforming stores and add new directors. Last month that it had fired 175 workers to save the company about $17 million a year in costs. The company also hired former TJX Cos. executive Alex Smith as CEO, replacing longtime chief Marvin J. Girouard.
A Fiserv In c. call center in Aurora, which employs more than 200 people, will close in the second quarter of 2010.

Halliburton Co. announced that it will cut about 1,000 jobs in the Eastern Hemisphere, effective immediately. The cuts are unrelated to the company's pending $35 million acquisition of Hughes Inc. and so far no cuts have occurred or are currently planned due to the proposed transaction.
Citigroup Inc. has fired about 30 workers in the structured-credit group after the company suffered billions of dollars of mortgage losses. The firings cut the group's size by nearly a third.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it will begin the gradual process of shutting down its Brook Park casting plant by the end of 2010, reducing the work force by an unspecified number. The company wants to get out of the business of making its own cast-iron engine blocks and vehicle parts, sending that work to suppliers in Canada and Brazil. With about 600 workers, Cleveland Casting is the largest of Ford's three Brook Park plants. Engine Plants No. 1 and No. 2 together employ about another 600. The company announced plans in 2007 to close the casting plant in 2009, but later agreed to extend its life another year. The company also does not have large layoffs scheduled before that date. The company does not classify ending the contracts of temporary workers as layoffs. Company and other union officials have argued that outsourcing all of Ford's engine-block castings is dangerous for the company because the automaker wouldn't have control over quality or pricing. The first casting to go will be the block for the 4.6-liter V-8 engine used in Ford's F-150 pickup and the outgoing version of the Explorer sport utility vehicle. Though jobs are leaving the casting plant, prospects are a bit better at Engine Plant No. 1. That facility makes the 3.7-liter V-6 engine used in the Mustang muscle car and the 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6, a turbocharged engine used in the Ford Taurus SHO and several other specialty vehicles. The company expects to add a second shift to that plant later this year as the automaker gets ready to put the EcoBoost V-6 in the F-150. Engineers have said the V-6 truck will be more powerful and significantly more fuel-efficient than some V-8 versions of the F-150, Ford's best-selling product for decades. The company expects the second shift at Engine Plant No. 1 to be added about the same time the casting plant closes, so many workers will transfer instead of losing their jobs. Still, the Brook Park site will need more new products to protect jobs there in the future. At Engine Plant No. 2, which employs about

The Boise Cascade Corp. is expected to close 45 of its recently acquired OfficeMax stores in the second quarter and eliminate 1,100 jobs. Of the 1,100 employees whose jobs are to be eliminated, Boise Cascade said, 500 will be offered transfers to other OfficeMax stores.

Interstate Bakeries Corp. announced that it is laying off 450 workers as it consolidates operations in three regions across the country. The bankrupt baker of Wonder Bread and Hostess Twinkies said the closure will eliminate the positions of store clerks, salespeople and delivery people in nine states by the end of the year.

GameStop Corp. is planning to close up to 130 GameStop stores. The closures of its GameStop stores represent 2% or less of its current collection of 6,457 stores. The company planning to add 300 to 400 of its technology branded stores as part of a partnership with AT&T Inc.è½within fiscal 2014. The company's technology brands Spring Mobile, Simply Mac and Cricket Wireless together will almost double their footprint in 2014. The company said the move to bolster its technology brands is simply to continue diversifying the company's offerings, but that its pre-used and digital sales have only been on the rise, something it expects to continue into fiscal 2014.

Spartan Stores Inc. will close three Food Town stores in Ohio next week as part of its ongoing efforts to dispose of the supermarket chain, but it is unclear whether the stores will stay shuttered or be sold and reopened under a new name. An official at the Food Town at 1415 Byrne Rd. in Toledo's Southland Shopping Center confirmed that the store will close, but no other information was available on the store's future.

Pfizer Inc.'s drug manufacturing plant in Sanford has been spared from closure in a realignment of Pfizer's worldwide manufacturing plant network, but the plant's work force will be cut almost in half by the end of 2015. Staffing at the Lee County facility, roughly 25 miles southeast of the Triad, is facing a reduction of another 400 jobs by the end of 2015. The plant, which currently employs about 850 employees in manufacturing and support, was part of Pfizer's $68 billion acquisition of rival drug maker Wyeth in late 2009. The global manufacturing plant realignment plan includes the closure of eight manufacturing plants in Richmond, Va.; two plants in New York, two plants in Puerto Rico and three plants in Ireland. In addition to the reductions in Sanford the company will be trimming operations at plants in Puerto Rico and Ireland, as well as one plant each in Andover, Mass.; Havant, U.K., and Illertissen, Germany. The global realignment plan is expected to reduce the company's global headcount by 6,000 people over the next several years. Workers who will lose their jobs as a result of the changes will receive severance benefits and other assistance to help with the transition, the company states. The company announced in November that it would layoff off 100 people who worked in research and development at the Sanford plant, which had about 1,000 employees at the time. The May 18, 2010 announcement will affect workers in Sanford's manufacturing operations.

Winn-Dixie and its sister supermarkets are closing 20 stores across the chain and cutting low-level management positions at supermarkets as well. One store is closing in Orlando on South Orange Blossom Trail at the end of May. The company has also begun eliminating lower-level management positions in departments across its grocery store chain, which also includes brands such as Bi-Lo, Harvey's and Fresco y Mas. The closings are spread across the chain, with the biggest hit coming in South Carolina, where six Bi-Lo stores are closing. Winn-Dixie has been going through a flurry of strategic changes since changing leadership about two years ago.

Brocade has announced it plans to cut 110 jobs, or 9% of its total workforce. The workforce reduction was planned after an analysis of all company operations conducted by internal teams in each department.
Callaway Golf has announced that it has laid off 100 employees due to the sluggish economy.

Dell Inc. plans to shift manufacturing from Limerick to Poland are gathering pace, as it ramps up production at its plant in Lodz and scales back staffing for the Irish plant. The computer giant will rehire only one-fifth of nearly 1,000 contract staff it has laid off in Limerick.

Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. is shutting down its cardboard manufacturing plant at 2525 S. Sunland Ave., in the Calwa neighborhood, as part of a consolidation of its regional operations. About 115 workers at a Fresno container plant are expected to lose their jobs over the next 12 months in a phased-down closure. The company is planning to close the Calwa plant in phases over the course of a year starting Nov. 23.

The Tech Data Corp. announced that it will immediately dismiss less than 2 percent of its 3,700-member work force. Tech Data also stated that the layoffs will affect its 2,500 employees in Clearwater.
VNU Group B.V. announced it will cut 4,000 jobs, or around 10% of its work force, as part of a major reorganization.

General Motors Corp. announced that it will eliminate 30,000 jobs and close all or part of 12 facilities as the automaker confronts the biggest threat to its survival since the onslaught of Japanese rivals led to a vast overhaul in the early 1990s. As part of the latest overhaul, GM will reduce its annual North American manufacturing capacity to 4.2 million vehicles by 2008, down from 6 million vehicles in 2002, a 30% reduction. The announcement adds 5,000 job cuts to the 25,000 the company promised in June, lowering GM's workforce to about 100,000 by the time the reductions are completed in 2008.

Bank of America announced the plans to cut about two dozen investment banking jobs in Asia, including some top dealmakers. Some bankers handling client coverage and deals will be made redundant, starting this week, with cuts expected in Hong Kong, Singapore and Japan, BofA's big centers in Asia. Bank of America's cuts will account for a small portion of its total Asia corporate and investment banking staff, and are part of an annual cost trimming.

PNC Financial Services Group Inc. announced that it plans to trim 10% of its work force in the next two years. The company announced a move to cut 5,800 jobs from its nearly 60,000-employee work force by 2011.

WellPoint Inc. announced that it will outsource its internal information technology help-desk functions, cutting about 100 positions. About 50 of the jobs are in the Richmond area, where the insurer operates Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield. Most of the other job cuts are in Indianapolis, where the company operates another computer help desk. A few workers scattered throughout the country also are affected.

BorgWarner Inc. announced to incur a $34 million charge in cash expenditure towards the already-announced closure of its Muncie, Indiana plant in the United States. The company had issued a final notice to its employees at its Muncie plant about the closure of the plant in the next couple of months.

Charming Shoppes Inc. announced that it plans to close 207 stores in the next year, including all its Added Dimensions and The Answer stores. The decision by the Bensalem-based retailer affects 1,900 workers, although company officials said job offers could be made in some of its remaining 2,300 stores. The targeted stores are losing money or are marginal performers, the company said. It did not disclose the locations of the stores to be closed. With the addition of the 651-store Lane Bryant chain purchased last year from The Limited Inc. Charming Shoppes has some 2,500 stores operating under seven brand names.
Cirrus Logic has announced that the company is reducing its workforce by 155 employees, about 13 percent of the workforce, as a part of its cost reduction efforts.
General Motors Co. will lay off up to 1,100 workers in South Korea due to rising costs.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. laid off 350 white-collar workers at its Akron headquarters in a sweeping cost-cutting move. Some of the highly trained, older workers have landed on their feet, but not all. And the tire maker expects more cuts in 2004, although it is uncertain if Akron will be affected.

Solutia Inc. is laying off 300 workers. The decision to idle the plant in Greenwood came because of the poor economy. The company has seen an unprecedented drop in demand for nylon in the past six weeks. The layoffs began in August, but many of them occurred last weekend. Some of the workers laid off worked directly for Solutia, while others worked at the plant through a contract company.
Staples slashed 1,400 jobs in third quarter, including 15% of its vice presidents and directors.

DuPont has announced that it plans to layoff six percent of its workforce and exit its polyester and nylon businesses as a part of its plan to cut costs in order to cope with the increased competition from Asian manufacturers.
United Technologies Corporation announced that it will be laying off approximately 5,000 employees, as part of a cost reduction plan.

Wells Fargo & Company and Edward D. Jones & Co., L.P. announced the closing of St. Louis Park Mortgage Subsidiary on March 7, 2013, with 214 Employees announced a Wells Fargo mortgage subsidiary with more than 200 employees in St. Louis Park is closing in March 2013. Edward Jones Mortgage, LLC notified the Minnesota Department of Employment and Economic Development that 214 Minnesota workers could lose their jobs. The St. Louis Park operation will close on March 7, 2013. About 210 employees are impacted by the closure, and the bank is helping them apply to job openings.

Dynegy's 1,488 MW coal-fired Brayton Point power plant in Somerset of US state Massachusetts will be closed on June 1, 2017. Dynegy is working with the town, its union partners and the community to complete the power plant shut down process smoothly. The decision to close the power plant was taken in 2013 before Dynegy acquired it from Equipower in April 2015. The four units of the power plant used to electrify about 1.5 million households when operated at full capacity. This is the last coal-fired power plant in US state Massachusetts.

International Speedway Corp. has cut more than 40 corporate positions at its headquarters. The company's goal of reducing by 20% the size of its headquarters staff, which numbered 250 at the start of the year 2010, has been met. Whether there will be additional job cuts will depend on the state of the economy.
PPG Industries announced that it has laid off about 400 employees at each facility due to the slumping demand in its marketplace.

Weyerhaeuser Co. plans to close its Woodburn lumber plant and lay off 57 workers as it continues to streamline operations following its merger with Willamette Industries. The plant will gradually reduce production and close by the end of the year.

Best Buy Co. Inc. will close seven of its big-box stores this fall in a slight shrinking of the company's national footprint. Six stores will close at the end of October. One is in Council Bluffs, Iowa; two are in the Baltimore area; one is in Topsham, Maine; one is in Beaufort, S.C.; and one is in Long Island, N.Y. A store in Willmar, Minn., will close in the next couple weeks. Two others, one in Chicago and one in Des Moines, closed earlier this year. In total Best Buy will close about 10 stores this year. Best Buy decided not to renew its leases, which has been the company's strategy for the past few years. Despite softness in electronics, the company under CEO Hubert Joly has resisted mass store closings.

Tollgrade Communications Inc. announced that it laid off 30 people about 10% of its workforce blaming weak demand for its telecommunications testing equipment. The staff cuts, primarily research and development posts, included 26 at its Cheswick facility. That reduced Tollgrade's work force to 162 locally and 285 corporatewide. The company expects to record a charge of $200,000 in the third quarter to account for the layoffs.
Kids 'R' Us has announced that it will close its stores in the Milwaukee area as part of the nationwide restructuring by its parent company, Toys 'R' Us.

Hibbett Sports, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 28, 2012. For the quarter, the company's net sales were $190,681,000 against $173,209,000 a year ago. Operating income was $25,052,000 against $19,302,000 a year ago. Income before provision for income taxes was $25,002,000 against $19,261,000 a year ago. Net income was $15,824,000 or $0.59 diluted per share against $12,457,000 or $0.44 diluted per share a year ago. For the full year, the company's net sales were $732,645,000 against $664,954,000 a year ago. Operating income was $93,531,000 against $73,547,000 a year ago. Income before provision for income taxes was $93,314,000 against $73,442,000 a year ago. Net income was $59,060,000 or $2.15 diluted per share against $46,400,000 or $1.60 diluted per share a year ago. The company spent $13 million in capital expenditure for the year versus a $13 million budget.For Fiscal 2013, the company expects to open 55 to 60 new stores, expand approximately 15 high performing stores. For fiscal year 2013, the company expects to close up to 18 stores. For the full year 2013, the company expects earnings with a range of $2.35 to $2.55 per diluted share (which includes an expected contribution of $0.07 to $0.09 per diluted share from the 53rd week) and comparable store sales to increase in the low to mid single digit range.Capital expenditure for 2012 will be a little more than $15 million.
Benchmark Electronics Inc. has reduced its workforce by 15 workers, and eliminated the third shift.

Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. announced that it will cut 500 jobs, or about 2%, of its total work force, citing losses in its investment portfolios and declining revenue. The company would slash jobs and other expenses to save $250 million in annual costs by the end of 2009.

Federal-Mogul Corp. announced it has laid off 103 workers at its Manitowoc plant that makes piston rings for heavy-duty diesel engines. The company previously announced it would cut shifts at the plant from three to two.

Patriot Coal Corporation announced that it will close three local mining operations in Kanawha and Boone counties between March 24 and April 6, 2009. Remington LLC, Highway Mining and Weatherby Processing have 220 employees who will lose their jobs. With other recent closures, 400 Patriot Coal employees in West Virginia will have lost their jobs. The operations being closed will include: The Deskins Mine in Kanawha County and Stockburg No. 2 in Boone County, as well as a Kanawha County mine office, which employ 143 hourly and salaried individuals. The Wildcat Surface and Highway Mining operations in Kanawha County, which employs 45. Weatherby's coal preparation plant, which employs 45. Patriot Coal explained it is shutting down its less productive operations, including the recent closure of the Jupiter mining complex in Boone County.

Meritor, Inc. announced that it will close its European trailer axle business on July 31, 2011. The company currently estimates that charges in the range of $17 million to $23 million will be incurred over 2012 in connection with these actions. Of these charges, an estimated $12 million to $18 million are expected to result in cash expenditures.

Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc. plans to announce about 1,600 layoffs after disclosing fourth-quarter write-downs. The layoffs are likely to be in trading positions and related areas, and will not likely include investment banking or private client groups. The company had about 64,000 employees as of the end of September, so the potential for 1,600 layoffs would represent less than 3% of the company's workforce.
Danaher Corp. will eliminate 1,700 jobs as part of a restructuring the company says will save it $100 million in 2009.

The Coca-Cola Co. announced that it would pay a former employee who blew the whistle on fraudulent activities at the soft drink giant $540,000 to settle a series of claims against the company. In return, ex-employee Matthew Whitley agreed to drop his complaints against the company and certain executives. In a joint statement, the two said Whitley will get the $140,000 entitled to him as severance from his layoff last spring, $100,000 to drop his cases in state and federal courts, and $300,000 to pay his attorneys fees. Whitley was seeking $44.4 million. 
 
 Whitley, a finance director for supply management at the fountain division, was among more than 1,000 people who lost their jobs in a sweeping reorganization in March. He claimed in the wrongful termination suit that he was fired because he complained about trumped-up numbers in a frozen Coke marketing test for Burger King five years ago, among other issues.

AOL Time Warner Inc. is expected to make more layoffs in its America Online unit next week. The America Online unit of the company has had job reductions of about 2,000 people in the past 18 months. Last year, it pared 725 jobs and 1,200 two summers ago. About 15,000 work for America Online in the U.S.

Visteon Corp. plans to close three plants and put another six up for sale under a restructuring plan that could affect up to 23 of its facilities worldwide. Under the new restructuring plan, Visteon plans to close plants in Monterrey, Mexico, and Rio Grande, Puerto Rico, in the first quarter of this year. It plans to close a third plant in Buffalo, N.Y., in the third quarter, although around 70 customer service and engineering employees at the Buffalo plant are expected to keep their jobs. It also plans to transfer 100 jobs from its plant in Swansea, Wales, to Ford. Visteon didn't release the total number of employees who could be affected. Visteon has around 15,800 employees in North America, including 11,000 hourly workers at 35 plants. The company has a total of 50,000 hourly and salaried employees at 170 facilities worldwide. In addition to the closures, Visteon trying to sell six plants and would give more details as talks progress. The company said it's working with 12 plants to transfer work to other facilities or close out product lines.

Bank of America Corporation announced that a sign the significant staff cuts announced as part of a company-wide initiative have begun. The bank would not comment on how many or where the layoffs were occurring. The bank announced in September that 30,000 positions would be eliminated as part of the Project New BAC cost-cutting program. A bank employee who spoke only on condition of anonymity also told McClatchy Newspapers that layoff notices were given to employees in the global learning division, which trains new hires and existing workers. The bank would not confirm that. Project New BAC began in April, a bid to streamline the company and restore investor confidence.

Alliant Techsystems announced that the Massachusetts leather-goods factory will shut down by July 31, 2009. The plant employs more than 300 people, mostly Latinos. Federal agents raided the plant and arrested more than 360 undocumented workers in 2007.

About 400 more people than expected will still have their jobs at The Boeing Co. Wichita at the end of the year. After the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, the company predicted it would need to reduce its work force by up to 5,200 employees by the end of 2002. Boeing Wichita general manager Jeff Turner told employees in a memo this week that cuts will total only 4,808. Spokesman Dick Ziegler said growth in Boeing Wichita's military programs mitigated total job cuts.

Western Union announced that it is laying off a 'significant portion' of its employees based out of a New Jersey office. The impacted employees of the office at 100 Summit Ave. in Montvale, New Jersey, will be laid off by Oct. 13, according to the Worker Readjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN) notice that the company filed with the state on Aug. 7. The letter, however, indicated that not all of the 192 'terminated' employees will leave the company.

Nearly half of the Company's 2,500 corporate payroll staff worldwide are impacted either through workforce reductions, salary reductions or reduced-hour work weeks. Under this plan, the Company will eliminate approximately 270 positions. The Company expects this initiative to be substantially complete in the second quarter of 2020 and that annual savings realized will be approximately $30 million.On March 30, 2020, the Company announced that Tom H. Barber will leave his role as Global Chief Development Officer, effective April 1, 2020. The Chief Development Officer for North America will now report directly to the President and Chief Executive Officer, and the development leaders for the Company's international regions will report to their respective regional presidents.

News Corp. may be preparing to layoff about half its 1,100 staff at MySpace, with termination notices to be distributed around mid-January as part of efforts to streamline the social-networking site ahead of a possible sale. Additional reductions in headcount will likely be necessary to lure a potential buyer, with News Corp. on track to complete a sale by mid-year.

Micron Technology Inc. announced that the officials hinted that more cuts and layoffs are to come at its Boise, Singapore and Xi'an, China, assembly and test facilities. While explaining that this round of layoffs has been much more targeted by function than the last round in 2003.

Albany International Corp. will spend $2.6 million closing down a Massachusetts plant later in 2008. The plant closing will impact about 80 people. More than half the employees will be offered relocation opportunities to other Albany International sites in the U.S. and Europe. About $2 million in cash will be spent on severance packages and other job termination benefits.

Cardinal Health Inc. will close a unit that trades in the secondary drug market where products are purchased from other drug wholesalers instead of directly from the drug makers. Cardinal Health will eliminate about 20 jobs by the end of June.
May Department Stores Company has announced that it plans to eliminate 100 jobs, approximately ten percent of its corporate headquarters staff, due to weak sales.

Centex Construction Products Inc. announced the closing of its aggregates quarry and crushing plant in Georgetown, Texas, north of Austin. The operation is owned by CXP subsidiary Centex Materials, LP. Centex Materials, which also operates a large crushed stone operation south of Austin in Buda, is a major producer of readymix concrete and aggregates products in the Austin area.

General Motors Co.'s salaried job cuts will include the elimination of 1,298 jobs at the Warren Technical Center. It appears the layoffs in Warren will continue until Feb. 28, which the company announced last day employees will appear in the company's payroll system. The automaker's Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification is dated Feb. 4, 2019. GM declined to comment on the specifics of the cuts to its roughly 20,000-person workforce in Warren.

The nation's biggest manufacturing site for Kellogg Company's snacks began laying off employees in Cary this morning as part of a corporate reorganization. The company is moving ahead with plans to cut $1 billion in annual costs, but would not disclose the number of local jobs to be cut. The facility manufactures Keebler crakers, Cheez-It crackers, Zoo animal crackers, Austin cookies, among other products. Earlier this year the plant suspended production of all peanut butter products during an outbreak of salmonella that sickened hundreds of people.
Lattice Semiconductor Corp. is cutting another 30 jobs and selling off one of its subsidiaries.

Pilgrim's Corp. announced to consolidate a pair of hatcheries and move jobs from De Queen to Nashville. The company has been operating beneath capacity at the two plants and decided to merge the operations. The move is expected to improve efficiency and make the Nashville hatchery more productive. All 21 workers at the De Queen plant will be offered jobs at other Pilgrim's Pride operations in southwest Arkansas. Operations at the De Queen facility are to be shut down by Sept. 16, 2011.

AOL Time Warner Inc. is planning another round of layoffs at its struggling Internet division in Dulles, as shaken employees continue to react to AOL's falling stock price and the departure of a top executive, according to company sources. The layoffs, however, are expected to be more surgical than across the board could be limited to about 60 of the 1,000 employees under de Castro, the sources said. Overall, the online division employs about 18,000.

The New York Times Company is planning to cut about 12 newsroom jobs at its flagship newspaper. About a dozen support positions at the paper will be eliminated, including a number of clerical and secretarial jobs. Next year the paper will eliminate a few management jobs in administrative areas. The job cuts will not include any journalists.

Capital One is cutting 750 jobs and will outsource much of the work performed by those employees to another company. The company said most of the job cuts will come from Capital One's offices in Federal Way and Richmond, Va. About 260 jobs at Federal Way will be eliminated by March 2005; the site will be closed.The company said it would transfer the work to a U.S.-based supplier.

Ruth's Hospitality Group, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2018. For the quarter, the company reported net income of $3,601,000 or $0.12 per diluted share compared to net income of $1,696,000 or $0.05 per diluted share reported in the same period last year. Artesyn Technologies Inc. announced that it will be laying off approximately 12 to 15 percent of its workforce, due to lowered second-quarter earnings forecasts.
Staples, Inc. plans to close approximately 50 stores in North America in 2016.
Walt Disney Co. to close Boulevard Mall's Disney one of 98 stores nationwide.

Ingersoll-Rand Co. Ltd. plans to cut several thousand jobs and close plants as sales in North America and Europe slow. The moves are part of a $110 million restructuring plan aimed at saving as much as $100 million in 2009. In an unrelated move, the company laid off 220 hourly workers this week from its Bridgeton plant. Excluding the 220 laid off-workers, the company employs about 1,270 hourly and salaried employees locally.

American Greetings Corp. has announced that it reached a deal with party goods maker Amscan Inc. and will stop making its own party goods. The move will result in a plant closing and about 225 facility-related job cuts. The Kalamazoo facility employs 225 people. Approximately 12 jobs will also be eliminated from the company's Cleveland headquarters. All of the positions are expected to be phased out between December and March.

Mattel Inc. announced that it will cut more than 200 jobs in the first quarter of this year, continuing a consolidation of its business that began last fall. The jobs will largely be cut from the company's headquarters in El Segundo, Calif. and represent about 1% of Mattel's worldwide staff. The cuts will be made through a combination of layoffs, attrition, retirements and elimination of open positions.

InfoSpace Inc. announced that it will lay off 250 of its approximately 620 employees. The layoffs have begun and will continue through the middle of 2007. The cuts will cost InfoSpace about $6.5 million in severance costs and between $6 million and $7 million for other charges.The company also announced that board member Ed Belsheim, who is also chief administrative officer, will leave the company on January 1, 2007.
Johnson Controls has announced that it plans to layoff 44 employees at its damper manufacturing plant in Watertown by October 2002.

Tenneco Inc. announced a major restructuring across its global operations designed to further reduce structural costs and capacity in response to the worsening industry downturn. The company intends to eliminate approximately 1,100 jobs worldwide, close five facilities and implement other cost reduction actions, which it expects will generate about $64 million in annual savings once fully implemented. The company intends to close four North America manufacturing facilities, restructure another manufacturing plant in North America, and close its Dunsborough, Australia engineering operation. The combination of these closures and other operational and administrative restructuring actions across its global operations will eliminate approximately 500 salaried positions and 600 hourly positions.
Nordstrom Inc. announced that it had laid off 1,600 employees nationwide including about 250 at its headquarters in downtown Seattle.

Terex Corp. recently announced plans to lay off workers from its aerial and crane divisions. Genie Industries, Terex's aerial division, is letting go of 184 workers at its Redmond, Wash., facility and 58 more in Moses Lake, Wash. Genie is shifting to a build-to-order model. The company hopes to cut an additional $100 million in costs by cutting work hours and managers' salaries. The cuts represent about 6% of Genie's workforce. Terex Cranes will lay off 114 workers from its Waverly, Iowa, manufacturing facility, and will shut down the plant from May 18 to June 19 and from August 3-7. The company will layoff 84 people from its 175-person production team and 30 people from its 135-person office staff.
Pepsico, Inc. is ending its bottling operation in Fargo, a move that will eliminate 16 jobs. The company's 302 warehouse and sales staff will not be affected.

Bank of America Corporation is laying off less than 5% of its investment banking staff and will tell employees about the cuts. The move would be the first significant organized reduction in the division's workforce. All units within the global banking and markets division, overseen by Tom Montag, will be affected. Even with the layoffs, the division is expected to have more employees at year's end than it did at the end of 2009. It was unclear how many people work in the division.

PeopleSoft Inc. said it will shed up to 1,000 employees or nearly 8 percent of its work force, during the next year as it tries to squeeze more profits from its $1.8 billion acquisition of Denver-based J.D. Edwards & Co. The streamlining will eliminate 750 to 1,000 jobs from a work force of about 13,000 employees. It layoffs will be concentrated in the administrative and marketing divisions.

SciClone Pharmaceuticals Inc. announced a corporate restructuring that will reduce its U.S. based workforce by approximately 17%, primarily in research and development.The company announced corporate restructuring that follows the discontinuation of company's RP101 phase 2 clinical trial announced on October 2, 2009. As a result of the restructuring, the company anticipates incurring a one-time severance-related charge of approximately $0.3 million, which includes severance and other expenses associated with the workforce reduction plan. The company expects to complete the restructuring in the fourth quarter of 2009.

Insight Enterprises Inc. announced actions to reduce its expense structure, based on the company's expectation of continued softness in the market's technology sector. The actions include a workforce reduction in its North America operations of approximately 270 employees or roughly 8% of its North America workforce.

Bank of America Corp. (DE) plans to cut 850 of the 1,500 jobs at the former Fleet Financial Corp. credit card center in suburban Philadelphia over the next year. The company plans to give Horsham workers priority in filling future vacancies and may eventually create new jobs there.

Johnson Controls Inc. has announced plans to cut more than 9,000 jobs, consolidating or closing 21 plants.The company announced a new contract to supply batteries to more than 1,000 Checker Auto Parts, Kragen Auto Parts and Schuck's Auto Supply stores nationwide. Shipments begin in February.

International Business Machines Corp. plans to trim its payroll by roughly 9,000 workers by the middle of this year. The jobs to be lost make up fewer than 3 percent of International Business Machines' worldwide work force of 320,000, but most of the cutbacks will come among the company's 160,000 employees in the United States.

Dean Foods Co. announced that production at a Lincoln dairy plant is ending, but workers can stay on the payroll another week to help close the doors. Nearly 100 people are losing their jobs as the Meadow Gold dairy plant stops producing milk and other dairy products on August 21, 2009. The company said that all of them can stay through August 28, 2009 to help with cleanup and other closing tasks. The company had planned to close the plant next month as part of a consolidation. Employees are getting severance. The company says about 70 people in sales and distribution will continue to work in Lincoln.

A. H. Belo Corporation will cut about 5% of the newspaper s jobs. The company plans to cut $50 million in expenses over the next eight months, partly by reducing the work force at its newspapers. The job cuts are the result of a broad restructuring that A.H. Belo announced it is implementing as it faces an unprecedentedly adverse business environment in the newspaper industry. As part of the plan, A.H. Belo announced it will eliminate the equivalent of about 500 full-time jobs company wide, representing about 14% of its overall work force of about 3,570 employees. The company announced that it has already eliminated the equivalent of 170 full-time jobs so far 2008 through attrition and disciplined hiring practices. The company also announced that it plans to sell some real estate in each of its three principal markets. The company also plans to reduce its overall marketing and promotional expense, travel expense and other discretionary expenses.
Nautica will close in the Great Mall of the Great Plains on July 5, 2009.

Deere & Co. announced that 40 employees of the John Deere Ottumwa Works will be placed on indefinite layoff later this month due to reduced market conditions for the factory's products. The layoff affects production workers with the least seniority. The company informed employees at the factory last week of the layoffs, which are effective April 20, 2009. The John Deere Ottumwa Works manufactures balers, mower conditioners, windrowers and pull-type forage harvesters used by hay and livestock producers.

United States Steel Corp. announced the proposed intent to permanently close its blast furnace and associated steelmaking operations, along with most of the flat-rolled finishing operations at Fairfield Works in Fairfield, Ala. Under this action, the blast furnace and associated steelmaking operations will be idled. They and the finishing operations would be permanently closed on or after Nov. 17, 2015. The facilities that would permanently close include the blast furnace and steelmaking operations, the hot strip mill, the pickle line, cold mill, annealing facility and stretch and temper line. The decision affects about 1,100 workers at the roughly century-old plant.

Cardinal Health Inc. announced that its Clinical and Medical Products businesses that are expected to be spun off later this year as CareFusion Corporation, will reduce its global workforce by approximately 800 over six months and eliminate an additional 500 positions through normal attrition and not filling open roles. In addition, Cardinal Health will implement cost control measures and additional reductions in discretionary spending across all of its businesses, primarily in response to a delay in hospital capital spending and the overall decline in the global economy. As part of the workforce reduction, Cardinal Health expects to record a restructuring charge of approximately $33 million for the remainder of fiscal 2009 and an additional charge of approximately $24 million in fiscal 2010. The company estimates this action will deliver annual savings of approximately $110 million to $130 million within two years.

Sears Holding Corp. will close its Kmart store in the Manahawkin section of Stafford. A liquidation sale at the store, located on Route 72, will begin on June 15. The store will close to the public in early September.

Lockheed Martin Corporation to lay off 51 employees at Naval Air Station Corpus Christi this summer once its defense contract expires. The company intends to cease operations and conduct layoffs on a periodic basis through July 31, when the government contract expires.
